Keywords: Monte Carlo Optimization, Black-box Optimization, Parametric Learning, Automated Annealing, Bias-variance-covariance

Parametric Learning and Monte Carlo Optimization

\nameDavid H. Wolpert \emaildhw@email.arc.nasa.gov
\addrMS 269-1, Ames Research Center
Moffett Field, CA 94035. \AND\nameDev G. Rajnayaran \emaildgorur@stanford.edu
\addrDepartment of Aeronautics and Astronautics,
Durand Rm. 158, 496 Lomita Mall, Stanford, CA 94305
Abstract

This paper uncovers and explores the close relationship between Monte Carlo Optimization of a parametrized integral (MCO), Parametric machine-Learning (PL), and â€˜blackboxâ€™ or â€˜oracleâ€™-based optimization (BO). We make four contributions. First, we prove that MCO is mathematically identical to a broad class of PL problems. This identity potentially provides a new application domain for all broadly applicable PL techniques: MCO. Second, we introduce immediate sampling, a new version of the Probability Collectives (PC) algorithm for blackbox optimization. Immediate sampling transforms the original BO problem into an MCO problem. Accordingly, by combining these first two contributions, we can apply all PL techniques to BO. In our third contribution we validate this way of improving BO by demonstrating that cross-validation and bagging improve immediate sampling. Finally, conventional MC and MCO procedures ignore the relationship between the sample point locations and the associated values of the integrand; only the values of the integrand at those locations are considered. We demonstrate that one can exploit the sample location information using PL techniques, for example by forming a fit of the sample locations to the associated values of the integrand. This provides an additional way to apply PL techniques to improve MCO.

1 Introduction

This paper uncovers and explores some aspects of the close relationship between Monte Carlo Optimization of a parametrized integral (MCO), Parametric machine Learning (PL), and â€˜blackboxâ€™ or â€˜oracle-basedâ€™ optimization (BO). We make four primary contributions. First, we establish a mathematical identity equating MCO with PL. This identity potentially provides a new application domain for all broadly-applicable PL techniques, viz., MCO.

Our second contribution is the introduction of immediate sampling. This is a new version of the Probability Collectives (PC) approach to blackbox optimization. PC encompasses Estimation of Distribution Algorithms (EDAs)(DeÂ Bonet etÂ al., 1997; Larraaga and Lozano, 2001; Lozano etÂ al., 2005) and the Cross Entropy (CE) methodÂ (Rubinstein and Kroese, 2004) as special cases. However PC is broader and more fully motivated. This means it uncovers (and overcomes) formal shortcomings in those other approaches.

In the immediate sampling version of PC the original BO problem is transformed into an MCO problem. In light of our first contribution, this means we can apply PL to immediate sampling. In this way aâ€‹lâ€‹lğ‘ğ‘™ğ‘™all PL techniques â€” including cross-validation, bagging, boosting, active learning, stacking, and others â€” can be applied to blackbox optimization.

In our third contribution we experimentally explore the power of this identity between MCO and PL. In these experiments we demonstrate that cross-validation and bagging improve the performance of immediate sampling blackbox optimization. In particular, in these experiments we show that cross-validation can be used to adaptively set an â€˜annealing scheduleâ€™ for blackbox optimization using immediate sampling without any extra calls to the oracle. In some cases, we show that this adaptively formed annealing schedule results in better optimization performance than any exponential annealing schedule.111Since they are special cases of PC, presumably we could similarly apply PL techniques to improve EDAâ€™s or the CE method.

Finally, conventional MC and MCO procedures ignore the relationship between the sample point locations and the associated values of the integrand. (Only the values of the integrand at the sample locations are considered by such algorithms.) We end by exploring ways to use PL techniques to exploit the information in the sample locations, for instance, by Bayesian fitting of a surface from the sample locations to the associated values of the integrand. This constitutes yet another way of applying PL to MCO in general, and therefore to BO in particular.

1.1 Background on PL, MCO, Blackbox Optimization, and PC

We begin by sketching the four disciplines discussed in this paper:

  1. 1.

    A large number of parametric machine-learning problems share the following two properties. First, the goal in these problems is to find a set of parameters, Î¸ğœƒ\theta, that minimizes an integral of a function that is parametrized by Î¸ğœƒ\theta. Second, to help us find that Î¸ğœƒ\theta we are are given samples of the integrand. These problems reduce to a sample-based search for the Î¸ğœƒ\theta that we predict minimizes the integral. We will refer to problems of this class as Parametric Learning (PL) problems.

    An example of PL is parametric supervised learning, where we want to find an optimal predictor or regressor zÎ¸subscriptğ‘§ğœƒz_{\theta} that minimizes the associated expected loss, âˆ«ğ‘‘xâ€‹ğ‘‘yâ€‹Pâ€‹(x)â€‹Pâ€‹(yâˆ£x)â€‹Lâ€‹[y,zÎ¸â€‹(x)]differential-dğ‘¥differential-dğ‘¦ğ‘ƒğ‘¥ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘¦ğ‘¥ğ¿ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘§ğœƒğ‘¥\int dx\,dy\;P(x)P(y\mid x)L[y,z_{\theta}(x)], where xğ‘¥xâ€™s are inputs and yğ‘¦yâ€™s are outputs. We do not, however, know Pâ€‹(x)â€‹Pâ€‹(yâˆ£x)ğ‘ƒğ‘¥ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘¦ğ‘¥P(x)P(y\mid x). Instead, we are provided a training set of samples of Pâ€‹(x)â€‹Pâ€‹(yâˆ£x)ğ‘ƒğ‘¥ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘¦ğ‘¥P(x)P(y\mid x). The associated PL problem is to use those samples to estimate the optimal Î¸ğœƒ\theta.

  2. 2.

    MCO is a technique for solving problems of the form argminâˆ«Ï•ğ‘‘wâ€‹Uâ€‹(w,Ï•)subscriptitalic-Ï•differential-dğ‘¤ğ‘ˆğ‘¤italic-Ï•{}_{\phi}\int dw\;U(w,\phi)Â (see Ermoliev and Norkin, 1998). MCO starts by replacing that integral with an importance-sample generated estimate of it. That estimate is a sum parametrized by Ï•italic-Ï•\phi. In MCO one searches for the value Ï•italic-Ï•\phi that minimizes this sum; the result of this search is oneâ€™s estimate of the Ï•italic-Ï•\phi that optimizes the original integral.

  3. 3.

    Blackbox optimization algorithms are ways to minimize functions of the form G:Xâ†’â„:ğºâ†’ğ‘‹â„G:X\rightarrow{\mathbb{R}} when one does not actually know the function GğºG. Such algorithms work by an iterative process in which they first select a query xâˆˆXğ‘¥ğ‘‹x\in X, and then an â€˜oracleâ€™ returns to the algorithm a (potentially noise-corrupted) value Gâ€‹(x)ğºğ‘¥G(x), and no other information, in particular, no gradient information. The difference between one blackbox optimization algorithm and another is how they select each successive query based on the earlier responses of the oracle. Examples of blackbox optimization algorithms are genetic algorithmsÂ (Mitchell, 1996), simulated annealingÂ (Kirkpatrick etÂ al., 1983), hill-climbing algorithms, Response-Surface Methods (RSMs)Â (Myers and Montgomery, 2002), and some forms of Sequential Quadratic Programming (SQP)Â (Gill etÂ al., 1981; Nocedal and Wright, 1999), Estimation of Distribution Algorithms (EDAs)(DeÂ Bonet etÂ al., 1997; Larraaga and Lozano, 2001; Lozano etÂ al., 2005), tabu search, the Cross Entropy (CE) methodÂ (Rubinstein and Kroese, 2004), and others.

  4. 4.

    PC is a set of techniques that can be used for blackbox optimization. Broadly speaking, PC works by transforming a search for the best value of a variable xğ‘¥x into a search for the best probability distribution over the variable, qâ€‹(x)ğ‘ğ‘¥q(x)Â (see Wolpert etÂ al., 2006; Macready and Wolpert, 2005; Wolpert, 2003, 2004a; Bieniawski and Wolpert, 2004; Antoine etÂ al., 2004; Lee and Wolpert, 2004). Once one solves for the optimal qâ€‹(x)ğ‘ğ‘¥q(x), inversion to get the optimal xğ‘¥x for the original search problem is stochastic; one simply samples qğ‘q. As described below, PC has many practical strengths, and is related to RSMs, EDAs, and the CE method.

1.2 Roadmap of This Paper

We make four primary contributions:

  1. 1.

    Sec.Â 2 begins with a detailed review of MCO and PL. Conventional analysis of Monte Carlo estimation involves a bias-variance decomposition of the error of the estimator of a particular integral. We show that for MCO, a full analysis requires more than simply extending such bias-variance analysis separately to each of the estimators given by the separate Ï•italic-Ï•\phiâ€™s. Moments coupling the errors of the estimators for the separate Ï•italic-Ï•\phiâ€™s must also be taken into account. How should we do that?

    To answer this, we note that in a different context, the techniques of PL take such coupling moments into account, albeit implicitly. This leads us to explore the relation between MCO and PL. This in turn leads to our first major contribution, the proof that MCO is identical to PL. This contribution means that one can apply all PL techniques, for instance, cross-validation, bagging, boosting, stacking, active learning and others, to MCO. Such PL-based MCO (PLMCO) provides a new way of minimizing potentially high-dimensional parametrized integrals.

    Experimentally testing the utility of applying PL to MCO requires an MCO application domain. Here we choose the domain of blackbox optimization. To establish how blackbox optimization is an application domain for MCO requires our second contribution, as follows.

  2. 2.

    We start in Sec.Â 3 by presenting an overview of previous versions of the blackbox optimization approach of PC. We then make our second contribution in the following section, where we introduce immediate sampling, a new version of PC that overcomes some of the limitations of previous versions.

    These first two contributions are combined by the fact that immediate sampling is a special case of MCO. The resultant identity between PL and immediate sampling means that, in principle, any PL technique can be applied to blackbox optimization. In particular, regularization, cross-validation, bagging, active learning, boosting, stacking, kernel machines, and others, can be â€˜cut and pasteâ€™ to do blackbox optimization. This use of PL for blackbox optimization constitutes a new application domain for PL.

    In Sec.Â 4.5 we present some concrete instances of how to modify immediate sampling to use PLMCO rather than conventional MCO. It is important to note that when applied (via immediate sampling) to blackbox optimization, these PL techniques do nâ€‹oâ€‹tğ‘›ğ‘œğ‘¡not require additional calls to the oracle. For example, using cross-validation to set regularization parameters in immediate sampling (the equivalent of an annealing schedule in SA) does not involve running the entire blackbox optimization algorithm with different regularization schedules. As another example, using bagging in immediate sampling does not mean running the optimization algorithm multiple times based on different subsets of the sample points found so far.

  3. 3.

    Our third contribution is to experimentally demonstrate in Sec.Â 5 that PLMCO substantially outperforms conventional MCO when used this way for blackbox optimization. We are particularly interested in blackbox optimization problems where calls to the oracle are the primary expense. Accordingly, non-oracle, â€˜offlineâ€™ computation is considered free. So in our experiments we compare algorithms based on the values of GğºG found by the algorithms versus the associated number of calls to the oracle222See Â Wolpert and Macready (1997); Droste etÂ al. (2002); Wolpert and Macready (2005); Corne and Knowles (2003); Igel and Toussaint (2004); Schumacher etÂ al. (2001) for a discussion of the mathematics relating algorithms under such performance measures.. In particular, we show that bagging and cross-validation leads to faster blackbox optimization on two well-known benchmark problems for continuous nonconvex optimization.

    It should be emphasized that these experiments are not intended to investigate whether PLMCO applied to immediate sampling is superior to other blackbox optimization algorithms. Rather their purpose is to investigate whether one can indeed leverage the formal connection between PL and MCO to improve immediate sampling. Accordingly, these experiments are on toy domains, and we do not compare performance with other blackbox optimization algorithms. We leave such comparisons to future papers.

  4. 4.

    In estimating the value of an integral based on random samples of its integrand, conventional MC and MCO techniques ignore how the locations of the sample points are related to the associated values of the integrand. Such techniques concentrate exclusively on those sample values of the integrand that are returned by the oracle. However, one can use the sample locations and associated integrand values to form a supervised learning fit to the integrand. In principle, such a fit can then be used to improve the overall estimate of the integral.

    In â€˜fit-basedâ€™ MC and MCO one uses all the data at hand to fit the integrand and then uses that fit to improve the algorithm. In this paper, we concentrate on situations where the data at hand consist only of sample locations and the associated values of the integrand, but in other situations the data at hand may also include information like the gradient of the integrand at the sample points. In their most general form, fit-based MC and MCO include techniques to exploit such information.

    One natural Bayesian approach to fit-based MC uses Gaussian processes. Work adopting this approach, for the case where the data only contain sample locations and associated integrand values, is reviewed in Â Rasmussen and Gharamani (2003). In Sec.Â 6 we generalize that work on fit-based MC, e.g., to allow non-Bayesian approaches. In that section, we also consider fit-based MCO in general, and fit-based immediate sampling in particular.

One of the ways cross-validation is used in these experiments is to set a regularization parameter. In immediate sampling, the regularization parameter plays the same role as the temperature does in simulated annealing. So intuitively speaking, our results show how to use cross-validation to set an annealing schedule adaptively for blackbox optimization, without extra calls to the oracle. We show in particular that such auto-annealing outperforms the best-fit exponential annealing schedule.

There are more topics involving the connection between MCO, immediate sampling and PL, than can be explored in this single paper. One such topic is how to incorporate constraints on xğ‘¥x in immediate sampling. Another important topic involves a derivation from first principles of the objective function used in immediate sampling. These two topics are briefly discussed in the appendices. Some other topics are mentioned, albeit even more briefly, in the conclusion.

1.3 Notation

As a point of notation, we will use the term â€˜distributionâ€™ to refer either to a probability distribution or a density function, with the associated Borel field implicitly fixing the meaning. Similarly, we will write integrals even when we mean sums; the measure of the integral is implicitly taken to be the one appropriate for the the argument. We will use Î˜Î˜\Theta to indicate the Heaviside or indicator function, which is 1 if its argument is positive, and 0 otherwise.

We will use ğ’«ğ’«\mathscr{P} to mean the set of all distributions over Xğ‘‹X. We are primarily interested in Xğ‘‹Xâ€™s that are too large to permit computations involving all members of ğ’«ğ’«\mathscr{P}. Accordingly, we will will work with parametrized subsets ğ’¬âŠ‚ğ’«ğ’¬ğ’«{\mathscr{Q}}\subset{\mathscr{P}}. We generically write that (possibly vector-valued)parameter as Î¸ğœƒ\theta, and write the element of ğ’¬ğ’¬\mathscr{Q} specified by Î¸ğœƒ\theta as qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta}. We use ğ”¼ğ”¼\mathbb{E} to indicate the expectation of a random variable. Subscripts on ğ”¼ğ”¼\mathbb{E} are sometimes used to indicate the distribution(s) defining the expectation.

We take any oracle ğ’¢ğ’¢{\mathscr{G}} to be an xğ‘¥x-indexed set of independent stochastic processes, and use the symbol gğ‘”g to indicate the generic output of the oracle in response to any query. With some abuse of notation, we denote the output of the oracle for query xğ‘¥x as Pâ€‹(gâˆ£x,ğ’¢)ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘”ğ‘¥ğ’¢P(g\mid x,{\mathscr{G}}). For a noise-free, or single-valued oracle, we write Pâ€‹(gâˆ£x,ğ’¢)=Î´â€‹(gâˆ’Gâ€‹(x))ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘”ğ‘¥ğ’¢ğ›¿ğ‘”ğºğ‘¥P(g\mid x,{\mathscr{G}})=\delta(g-G(x)) for some function GğºG implicitly specified by ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathscr{G}, where Î´(.)\delta(.) is the Dirac delta function.

When there is both a factual version of a random variable and a posterior distribution over counter-factual values of that variable, they must be distinguished. In general this requires extending the conventional Bayesian formalismÂ (see Wolpert, 1997, 1996). Here, though, it suffices for us to indicate counter-factual values by a subscript cğ‘c. Say there is a factual oracle ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathscr{G}, and we are provided a data set Dğ·D formed by sampling ğ’¢ğ’¢\mathscr{G}. We use superscripts to denote different samples in that data set. Then Dğ·D in turn induces a posterior over oracles, and we write that posterior as Pâ€‹(ğ’¢câˆ£D)ğ‘ƒconditionalsubscriptğ’¢ğ‘ğ·P({\mathscr{G}}_{c}\mid D).

2 MCO and PL

In this section we review PL and MCO show that they are mathematically identical.

2.3 Statistical Analysis of MCO

The statistical analysis of MC estimation of integrals is a relatively mature fieldÂ (see Robert and Casella, 2004; Fishman, 1996). We now show that when such MC estimation is combined with parameter optimization in MCO, the analysis becomes much more involved.

2.3.1 Review: MC Estimation

First consider MC estimation, with no mention of MCO. We first need to to specify a loss function L(.,.)L(.,.) that will couple our mathematics with real-world costs. The first argument of such an Lğ¿L is the output of the estimation algorithm under consideration. The second argument is the quantity statistically sampled by that algorithm. The associated value of Lğ¿L is the cost if the algorithm produces the output specified in that first argument, using the quantity specified in the second argument.

As an example, consider importance-sampled MC estimation of an integral. Using the MCO notation just introduced, we use â„’^â€‹(Ï•)^â„’italic-Ï•{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) as an estimate of â„’â€‹(Ï•)â„’italic-Ï•{\mathscr{L}}(\phi) for some fixed Ï•italic-Ï•\phi. The quantity being sampled is the function U(.,Ï•)U(.,\phi), and the output of the algorithm is â„’^â€‹(Ï•)^â„’italic-Ï•{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi). Accordingly, these are the arguments of the loss function.

The most popular loss function in statistical analysis of MC integral estimation is quadratic loss, given below.

L(â„’^(Ï•),U(.,Ï•))\displaystyle L({\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi),U(.,\phi)) â‰œâ‰œ\displaystyle\triangleq [â„’^â€‹(Ï•)âˆ’âˆ«ğ‘‘wâ€‹Uâ€‹(w,Ï•)]2.superscriptdelimited-[]^â„’italic-Ï•differential-dğ‘¤ğ‘ˆğ‘¤italic-Ï•2\displaystyle[{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi)-\int dw\;U(w,\phi)]^{2}.

Unless explicitly stated otherwise, we will henceforth use the term â€˜expected lossâ€™ to refer to the average of this loss function over sample sets. Since â„’^â€‹(Ï•)^â„’italic-Ï•{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) is an unbiased estimate of â„’â€‹(Ï•)â„’italic-Ï•{\mathscr{L}}(\phi), the expected loss is the sample variance,

This expansion for the sample variance is quite useful. For example, one can solve for the vğ‘£v that minimizes this variance (and therefore minimizes expected loss) as a function of U(.,Ï•)U(.,\phi). For nowhere-negative Uğ‘ˆU, that optimal vğ‘£v is given by Â (see Robert and Casella, 2004)

Given the formula for the optimal vğ‘£v, one can estimate it from a current sample set, and then use the estimated optimal vğ‘£v for future sampling. This is what is done in the VEGAS AlgorithmÂ (Lepage, 1978, 1980). Consideration of the sample variance has also led to algorithms that partition Xğ‘‹X and then run importance sampling on each partition element separately, for instance, stratified samplingÂ (Fishman, 1996). MC estimators that do not use strict importance sampling may introduce bias. However, if the variance is sufficiently reduced, expected quadratic error is reduced. This can be exploited to tradeoff bias and variance.

2.3.2 From MC to MCO

When we combine MC with parameter optimization in MCO, quantities like Varâ€‹(â„’^â€‹(Ï•))Var^â„’italic-Ï•{\mbox{Var}}({\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi)) for one particular Ï•italic-Ï•\phi are not the main objects of interest. Instead, we are interested in expected loss of our iterated MCO algorithm, which involves multiple Ï•italic-Ï•\phiâ€™s. So what is the appropriate loss function for analyzing MCO? From the very definition of (P2), it is clear that we want Lâ€‹(Ï•,U)ğ¿italic-Ï•ğ‘ˆL(\phi,U) to be minimized by the Ï•italic-Ï•\phi that minimizes âˆ«ğ‘‘wâ€‹Uâ€‹(w,Ï•)differential-dğ‘¤ğ‘ˆğ‘¤italic-Ï•\int dw\;U(w,\phi). The simplest approach to doing this, which will be assumed from now on, stipulates that

Lâ€‹(Ï•,U)=â„’â€‹(Ï•)=âˆ«ğ‘‘wâ€‹Uâ€‹(w,Ï•),ğ¿italic-Ï•ğ‘ˆâ„’italic-Ï•differential-dğ‘¤ğ‘ˆğ‘¤italic-Ï•\displaystyle L(\phi,U)\;\;=\;\;{\mathscr{L}}(\phi)\;\;=\;\;\int dw\;U(w,\phi), (4)

the same integral appearing in (P2). If we can solve (P2) exactly, then we will have produced the Ï•italic-Ï•\phi with minimal value of this loss function.

There is no direct relation between this vğ‘£v and the one that minimizes loss for some single Ï•italic-Ï•\phi. In stark contrast to the MC analysis in Sec.Â 2.3.1, in addition to the sample variance Varâ€‹(â„’^â€‹(Ï•))Var^â„’italic-Ï•{\mbox{Var}}({\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi)) for any single Ï•italic-Ï•\phi, the expected loss ğ”¼â€‹(Lâˆ£U,v)ğ”¼conditionalğ¿ğ‘ˆğ‘£{\mathbb{E}}(L\mid U,v) now also depends on moments coupling the distributions of â„’^â€‹(Ï•)^â„’italic-Ï•\hat{\mathscr{L}}(\phi) for different Ï•italic-Ï•\phiâ€™s. Loosely speaking, the bias-variance tradeoff in Sec.Â 2.3.1 now becomes a more complicated bias-variance-covariance tradeoff. Now, setting wğ‘¤w is more involved, but we can approach it as follows.

Expressing the expected loss slightly differently gives us an important insight. Note that each sample set {wi}superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–\{w^{i}\} gives rise to an associated set of estimates for all Ï•âˆˆÎ¦italic-Ï•Î¦\phi\in\Phi. Call this (possibly infinite dimensional) vector of estimates lâ†’â†’ğ‘™\vec{l}, each of whose components is indexed by Ï•italic-Ï•\phi and is an estimate for that particular Ï•italic-Ï•\phi. Now, instead of computing expected loss by averaging over all possible sample sets, we average over all possible vectors lâ†’â†’ğ‘™\vec{l}. In order to do this, we need to specify the probability of each vector lâ†’â†’ğ‘™\vec{l}. Define

Ï€v,U,Î¦â€‹(lâ†’)subscriptğœ‹ğ‘£ğ‘ˆÎ¦â†’ğ‘™\displaystyle\pi_{v,U,\Phi}({\vec{l}}) â‰œâ‰œ\displaystyle\triangleq Pr({wi}:â„’^v,U,{wi}(Ï•)=lÏ•âˆ€Ï•âˆˆÎ¦).\displaystyle{\mbox{Pr}}(\{w^{i}\}:{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}_{v,U,\{w^{i}\}}(\phi)=l_{\phi}\;\;\forall\phi\in\Phi).

where â€˜argmin[lÏ•]Ï•{}_{\phi}[l_{\phi}]â€™ means the index Ï•italic-Ï•\phi of the smallest component of lâ†’â†’ğ‘™\vec{l}. The risk is the difference between this expected loss and the lowest possible loss. We can write that risk as

âˆ«ğ‘‘lâ†’â€‹Ï€v,U,Î¦â€‹(lâ†’)â€‹[â„’â€‹(argminÏ•â€‹[lÏ•])âˆ’minÏ•â€‹[â„’â€‹(Ï•)]].differential-dâ†’ğ‘™subscriptğœ‹ğ‘£ğ‘ˆÎ¦â†’ğ‘™delimited-[]â„’subscriptargminitalic-Ï•delimited-[]subscriptğ‘™italic-Ï•subscriptminitalic-Ï•delimited-[]â„’italic-Ï•\displaystyle\int d{\vec{l}}\;\pi_{v,U,\Phi}({\vec{l}})\;[{\mathscr{L}}({\mbox{argmin}}_{\phi}[l_{\phi}])\;-\;{\mbox{min}}_{\phi}[{\mathscr{L}}(\phi)]]. (7)

Our sample set constitutes a set of samples of Ï€v,U,Î¦subscriptğœ‹ğ‘£ğ‘ˆÎ¦\pi_{v,U,\Phi} occurring in Eq.Â 6,This fact can potentially be exploited to dynamically modify vğ‘£v and/or Î¦Î¦\Phi to reduce ğ”¼â€‹(Lâˆ£U,v)ğ”¼conditionalğ¿ğ‘ˆğ‘£{\mathbb{E}}(L\mid U,v). Indeed, for the simpler case of MC estimation, this is essentially the kind of computation done in the VEGAS algorithm mentioned above. As a practical issue, it may be difficult to update vğ‘£v and/or Î¦Î¦\Phi using the full formula Eq.Â 5. Instead, one could approximate that formula ğ”¼â€‹(Lâˆ£U,v)ğ”¼conditionalğ¿ğ‘ˆğ‘£{\mathbb{E}}(L\mid U,v) near a single Ï•italic-Ï•\phi of interest, e.g., about a current estimate for the optimal Ï•italic-Ï•\phi.

Intuitively though, one would expect that for a fixed set of Ï•italic-Ï•\phiâ€™s, everything else being equal, it would be advantageous to have small variances of unbiased estimators and large covariances between them. Such considerations based on the second moments may help one choose quantities like the sampling distribution vğ‘£v.

Such considerations may also help one choose the set of candidate Ï•italic-Ï•\phiâ€™s, Î¦Î¦\Phi. For example, one way to have large covariances between the Ï•âˆˆÎ¦italic-Ï•Î¦\phi\in\Phi is to have the associated functions over wğ‘¤w, {U(.,Ï•):Ï•âˆˆÎ¦}U(.,\phi):\phi\in\Phi\}, all lie close to one another in an appropriate function space (e.g., according to an lâˆsubscriptğ‘™l_{\infty} norm comparing such functions). However, choosing such a Î¦Î¦\Phi will tend to mean there is a small â€˜coverageâ€™ of that set of functions, {U(.,Ï•):Ï•âˆˆÎ¦}U(.,\phi):\phi\in\Phi\}. More precisely, it will tend to prevent the best of those Ï•italic-Ï•\phiâ€™s from being very good; min[âˆ«dwU(w,Ï•)]Ï•âˆˆÎ¦{}_{\phi\in\Phi}[\int dw\;U(w,\phi)] will not be very low.

This illustrates that, in choosing Î¦Î¦\Phi, there will be a tradeoff between two quantities: The first quantity is the best possible performance with any of the Ï•âˆˆÎ¦italic-Ï•Î¦\phi\in\Phi. The second quantity is the risk, that is, how close a given MCO algorithm operating on Î¦Î¦\Phi is likely to come to that best possible performance of a member of Î¦Î¦\Phi. Choosing Î¦Î¦\Phi to have large covariances of the (MC estimators based on the) members of Î¦Î¦\Phi, and in particular to have large covariances with the truly optimal Ï•italic-Ï•\phi, argminâ„’Ï•âˆˆÎ¦â€‹(Ï•)subscriptâ„’italic-Ï•Î¦italic-Ï•{}_{\phi\in\Phi}{\mathscr{L}}(\phi), will tend to result in low risk. But it will also tend to result in poor best-possible performance over all Ï•âˆˆÎ¦italic-Ï•Î¦\phi\in\Phi.

Similarly, one would expect that as the size of Î¦Î¦\Phi increases, there would be a greater chance that a sample set for one of the suboptimal Ï•âˆˆÎ¦italic-Ï•Î¦\phi\in\Phi would have low expected loss â€˜by luckâ€™. This would then mislead one into choosing that suboptimal Ï•italic-Ï•\phi. So increasing the size of Î¦Î¦\Phi may increase risk. However increasing Î¦Î¦\Phiâ€™s size should also improve best possible performance. So again, we get a tradeoff.

It may be that such considerations involving the size of Î¦Î¦\Phi and the covariances of its members can be encapsulated in a single number, giving an â€˜effective sizeâ€™ of Î¦Î¦\Phi (somewhat analogously to the VC dimension of a set of functions). Such tradeoffs are specific to the use of MCO, and do not arise in plain (single-Ï•italic-Ï•\phi) MC. They are in addition to the usual bias-variance tradeoffs, which still apply to each of the separate MC estimators.

An illustrative example of the foregoing is provided in App.Â C. A more complete statistical analysis of risk in MCO, including Bayesian considerations, is in Sec.Â 6.

2.4 PL Equals MCO

In MCO, we have to extrapolate from the sample set of wğ‘¤w values to perform the integral minimization in Eq.Â 3. As discussed above, this can recast as having a set of sample functions Ï•â†’riâ€‹(Ï•)â†’italic-Ï•superscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–italic-Ï•\phi\rightarrow r^{i}(\phi) that we want to use to estimate the Ï•italic-Ï•\phi that achieves that minimization. Similarly, in PL, we have to extrapolate from a training set of functions Riâ€‹(Î¾)superscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğœ‰R^{i}(\xi) to minimize the integral âˆ«ğ‘‘xâ€‹Pâ€‹(x)â€‹Rxâ€‹(Î¾)differential-dğ‘¥ğ‘ƒğ‘¥subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¥ğœ‰\int dx\;P(x)R_{x}(\xi). Though not usually viewed this way, at the root of this extrapolation problem is the problem of using the sample functions Î¾â†’Riâ€‹(Î¾)â†’ğœ‰superscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğœ‰\xi\rightarrow R^{i}(\xi) to estimate the minimizer of Eq.Â 2.

In addition, the analysis of Sec.Â 2.3 is closely related to the PL field of uniform convergence theory. That field can be cast in the terms of the current discussion as considering a broad class of Uğ‘ˆUâ€™s, ğ’°ğ’°\mathscr{U}. Its starting point is the establishment of bounds on how

All of this suggests that the general MCO problem of extrapolation from a sample set of empirical functions to minimize the integral of Eq.Â 3, is, in fact, identical to the general PL problem of extrapolation from a training set of empirical functions to minimize the integral of Eq.Â 2. This is indeed the case. As shown in TableÂ 1, identify Î¾â†”Ï•,xâ†”w,Pâ€‹(x)â†”vâ€‹(w),Rxâ€‹(Î¾)â†”rv,wâ€‹(Ï•),rviâ€‹(Ï•)â†”Riâ€‹(Î¾)â†”ğœ‰italic-Ï•ğ‘¥â†”ğ‘¤ğ‘ƒğ‘¥â†”ğ‘£ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¥ğœ‰â†”subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘£ğ‘¤italic-Ï•subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘£italic-Ï•â†”superscriptğ‘…ğ‘–ğœ‰\xi\leftrightarrow\phi,x\leftrightarrow w,P(x)\leftrightarrow v(w),R_{x}(\xi)\leftrightarrow{r}_{v,w}(\phi),r^{i}_{v}(\phi)\leftrightarrow R^{i}(\xi). Then the integrals in Eq.Â 3 and (P1) become identical. So the MCO expected loss function in Eq.Â 4 becomes identical to the PL expected loss. Similarly, the sample functions for MCO and PL become identical.

In particular, in supervised learning, when there is no noise, Pâ€‹(yâˆ£x)ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘¦ğ‘¥P(y\mid x) becomes a single-valued function yâ€‹(x)ğ‘¦ğ‘¥y(x), and the parametric supervised learning problem becomes

argminÎ¾â€‹âˆ«ğ‘‘xâ€‹Pâ€‹(x)â€‹[Lâ€‹(yâ€‹(x),zÎ¾â€‹(x))]subscriptargminğœ‰differential-dğ‘¥ğ‘ƒğ‘¥delimited-[]ğ¿ğ‘¦ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘§ğœ‰ğ‘¥\displaystyle{\mbox{argmin}}_{\xi}\int dx\;P(x)[L(y(x),z_{\xi}(x))]

This should be compared to the MCO problem as formulated in Eq.Â 3. For the same reasons that direct minimization of Eq.Â 1 is seldom used in PL, we now see that naive MCO will be biased, and should preferably not be used directly.

Note that most sampling theory analysis of PL does not directly consider the biases and variances of the separate Monte Carlo estimators for each Î¾ğœ‰\xi, nor does it directly consider the moments that couple the distributions of those estimates. Rather, it considers a different type of bias and variance â€” the bias and variance of an entire algorithm that chooses a Î¾ğœ‰\xi based on associated MC estimates of expected lossÂ (Wolpert, 1997). In this sense, such PL analysis bypasses the issues considered in Sec.Â 2.3. The bias-variance-covariance approach described in this section might have important implications on PL analysis of learning algorithms, but for the moment, in our exploration of the identity between MCO and PL, we simply use PL-based techniques to reduce the bias or variance of our algorithms.

3 Review of PC

This section cursorily reviews the previously investigated type of PC. It then briefly discusses the advantages of PC for blackbox optimization and its relation to other blackbox optimization techniques.

3.1 Introduction to PC

To introduce PC, consider the general (not necessarily blackbox) optimization problem

(P4)::P4absent\displaystyle\mathrm{(P4):} argminxâˆˆXâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹(gâˆ£x,ğ’¢).subscriptargminğ‘¥ğ‘‹ğ”¼conditionalğ‘”ğ‘¥ğ’¢\displaystyle{\mbox{argmin}}_{x\in X}{\mathbb{E}}(g\mid x,{\mathscr{G}}).

For now, we ignore constraints on xğ‘¥x. In PC we transform (P4) into the problem

(P5)::P5absent\displaystyle\mathrm{(P5):} argminqÎ¸âˆˆğ’¬â€‹â„±ğ’¢â€‹(qÎ¸),subscriptargminsubscriptğ‘ğœƒğ’¬subscriptâ„±ğ’¢subscriptğ‘ğœƒ\displaystyle{\mbox{argmin}}_{q_{\theta}\in{\mathscr{Q}}}{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(q_{\theta}),

for some appropriate function â„±ğ’¢subscriptâ„±ğ’¢{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}. After solving (P5) we stochastically invert qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} to get an xğ‘¥x (the ultimate object of interest), by sampling qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta}. This type of â€œrandomizing transformâ€ contrasts with conventional transform techniques, where inversion is deterministic.

Ideally, â„±ğ’¢subscriptâ„±ğ’¢{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}} should be chosen in a first-principles manner, based on exactly how qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} will be sampled and how those samples used (see Sec.Â 6). In practice though, computational considerations might lead one to choose â„±ğ’¢subscriptâ„±ğ’¢{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}} heuristically. Intuitively, such considerations might compel us to choose â„±ğ’¢subscriptâ„±ğ’¢{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}} both so that (P5) is readily easy to solve, and so that any solution qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} to (P5) is concentrated about the solutions of (P4). However, there are several â€˜data-agingâ€™ heuristics one can employ to reuse such old data by down-weighting it.

In all these schemes, while we ultimately use Monte Carlo in the PC, it is delayed as long as possible in the course of solving (P5). This is the basis for calling this variant of PC â€˜delayed samplingâ€™.

3.3 Advantages of PC

The PC transformation can substantially alter the optimization landscape. For a noise-free oracle Gâ€‹(x)ğºğ‘¥G(x), (P4) reduces to the problem of finding the xğ‘¥x that minimizes Gâ€‹(x)ğºğ‘¥G(x). In contrast, (P5) is the problem of finding the Î¸ğœƒ\theta that minimizes â„±ğ’¢â€‹(Î¸)subscriptâ„±ğ’¢ğœƒ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta). The characteristics of the problems of minimizing Gâ€‹(x)ğºğ‘¥G(x) and minimizing â„±ğ’¢â€‹(Î¸)subscriptâ„±ğ’¢ğœƒ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta) can be vastly different. For example, suppose qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} is log-concave in its parameters, and â„±ğ’¢subscriptâ„±ğ’¢{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}} is pâ€‹qğ‘ğ‘pq KL distance. In this case, regardless of the function Gâ€‹(x)ğºğ‘¥G(x), â„±ğ’¢â€‹(Î¸)subscriptâ„±ğ’¢ğœƒ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta) is a convex function of Î¸ğœƒ\theta, over ğ’¬ğ’¬{\mathscr{Q}}. So the PC transformation converts a problem with potentially many local minima into a problem with none. SeeÂ Wolpert etÂ al. (2006) for a discussion of the geometry of the surface â„±ğ’¢â€‹(Î¸):Î¸â†’â„:subscriptâ„±ğ’¢ğœƒâ†’ğœƒâ„{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta):\theta\rightarrow{\mathbb{R}}.

Since it works directly on distributions, PC can handle arbitrary data types. Xğ‘‹X can be categorical, real-valued, integer-valued, or a mixture of all of these, but in each case, the distribution over Xğ‘‹X is parametrized by a vector of real numbers. This means that all such problems â€˜look the sameâ€™ to much of the mathematics of PC. Moreover, PC can exploit extremely well-understood techniques (like gradient descent) for optimization of continuous functions of real-valued vectors, and apply them to problems in these arbitrary spaces.

Optimizing over distributions can give sensitivity information: The distribution qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} produced in PC will typically be tightly peaked along certain directions, while being relatively flat along other directions. This tells us the relative importance of getting the value of xğ‘¥x along those different directions precisely correct.

We can set the initial distribution for PC to be a sum of broad peaks, each centered on a solution produced by some other optimization algorithm. Then, as that initial distribution gets updated in the PC algorithm, the set of solutions provided by those other optimization algorithms are in essence combined, to produce a solution that should be superior to any of them individually.

Yet another advantage to optimizing a distribution is that a distribution can easily provide multiple solutions to the optimization problem, potentially far apart in Xğ‘‹X. Those solutions can then be compared by the analyst in a qualitative fashion.

As discussed later, there are other advantages that accrue specifically if one uses the immediate-sampling variant of PC. These include the ability to reuse all old data, the ability to exploit prior knowledge concerning the oracle, and the ability to leverage PL techniques. SeeÂ Wolpert etÂ al. (2006) for a discussion of other advantages of PC, in particular in the context of distributed control.

3.4 Relation to Other Work

PC is related to several other optimization techniques. Consider, for instance, Response Surface Models (RSM)sÂ Jones etÂ al. (1998). In these techniques, one uses Design of Experiments (DOE) to evaluate the objective function at a set of points. Then, a low-order parametric function, often a quadratic, is fitted to these function values. Optimization of this â€˜response surfaceâ€™ or â€˜surrogate modelâ€™ is considered trivial compared to the original optimization. The result of this surrogate optimization is then used to get more samples of the true objective at a different set of points. This procedure is then iterated using some heuristics, often in conjunction with trust-region methods to ensure validity of the low-order approximation. We note the similarities with PC in TableÂ 2.

As another example, some variants of PC exploit MC techniques as discussed above, and thus stochastically generate populations of samples. In their use of random populations these variants of PC are similar to simulated annealingÂ (Kirkpatrick etÂ al., 1983), and even more so to techniques like EDAâ€™sÂ Larraaga and Lozano (2001); DeÂ Bonet etÂ al. (1997); Lozano etÂ al. (2005) and the CE methodÂ (Rubinstein and Kroese, 2004). However, these other approaches do not explicitly pursue the optimization of the underlying distribution qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta}, as in (P5). Accordingly, those approaches cannot exploit situations in which (P5) can be solved without using a stochastically generated populationÂ (Macready and Wolpert, 2005, 2004). SeeÂ Macready and Wolpert (2005) for a more extensive discussion of the relation of PC to other techniques.

4 Immediate sampling

This section introduces a new PC technique called immediate sampling, and cursorily compares it to delayed sampling. As we have just described, in delayed sampling, we use algebra for as long as possible in our solution of (P5). When closed-form expressions can no longer be evaluated, we resort to MC techniques. In immediate sampling, we form an MC sample immediately, rather than delaying it as long as possible. That sample gives us an approximation to our objective, â„±ğ’¢â€‹(Î¸)subscriptâ„±ğ’¢ğœƒ\mathscr{F}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta) for all Î¸âˆˆğ’¬ğœƒğ’¬\theta\in{\mathscr{Q}}. We then search for the Î¸ğœƒ\theta that optimizes that sample-based approximate objective.

4.1 The General Immediate-sampling Algorithm

4.2 Immediate Sampling with Multiple Sample Sets

In general, we will not end the algorithm after forming a single sample set D1superscriptğ·1D^{1}. Instead we will use a map Î·ğœ‚\eta that takes D1superscriptğ·1D^{1} to a new sampling distribution, h2superscriptâ„2h^{2}. We then generate new (x,g)ğ‘¥ğ‘”(x,g) pairs using h2superscriptâ„2h^{2}, giving us a new sample set D2superscriptğ·2D^{2}. We then iterate this process until we decide to end the algorithm, at which point we use all our samples sets together to estimate argminâ„±ğ’¢Î¸â€‹(qÎ¸)subscriptsubscriptâ„±ğ’¢ğœƒsubscriptğ‘ğœƒ{}_{\theta}{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(q_{\theta}).

To illustrate this we first present an example of a Î¸ğœƒ\theta-estimation procedure we could run at the end of the immediate sampling algorithm. This example is just the extension of the maximum likelihood Î¸ğœƒ\theta-estimation procedure introduced above to accommodate multiple sample sets. Let Nğ‘N be the total number of samples, drawn from Mğ‘€M sample sets, with Njsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—N_{j} samples in the jğ‘—jâ€™th sample set. Let hjsuperscriptâ„ğ‘—h^{j} be sample distribution for the jğ‘—jâ€™th sample set, and ri,jsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘—r^{i,j} the sample function value for the iğ‘–iâ€™th element of the jğ‘—jâ€™th sample set. Also define Djâ‰¡{xi,j,gi,j:i=1,â€¦â€‹Nj}superscriptğ·ğ‘—conditional-setsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘—D^{j}\equiv\{x^{i,j},g^{i,j}:i=1,\ldots N_{j}\}. Then âˆ‘i=1Njrhji,jâ€‹(xi,j,Î¸)/Njsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptâ„ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœƒsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—\sum_{i=1}^{N_{j}}r^{i,j}_{h^{j}}(x^{i,j},\theta)/N_{j} is an unbiased estimate of â„±ğ’¢â€‹(qÎ¸)subscriptâ„±ğ’¢subscriptğ‘ğœƒ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(q_{\theta}) for any sample set jğ‘—j. Accordingly, any weighted average of these estimates is an unbiased estimate of â„±ğ’¢â€‹(qÎ¸)subscriptâ„±ğ’¢subscriptğ‘ğœƒ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(q_{\theta}):

â„±ğ’¢â€‹(qÎ¸)subscriptâ„±ğ’¢subscriptğ‘ğœƒ\displaystyle{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(q_{\theta}) â‰ˆ\displaystyle\approx âˆ‘j=1Mwjâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Njrhji,jâ€‹(xi,j,Î¸)Nj.superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘€subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptâ„ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœƒsubscriptğ‘ğ‘—\displaystyle\displaystyle\displaystyle\sum_{j=1}^{M}w_{j}\sum_{i=1}^{N_{j}}\frac{r^{i,j}_{h^{j}}(x^{i,j},\theta)}{N_{j}}. (15)

Modulo unbiasedness concerns, we could then use the minimizer of Eq.15 as our estimate of argminâ„±ğ’¢Î¸â€‹(qÎ¸)subscriptsubscriptâ„±ğ’¢ğœƒsubscriptğ‘ğœƒ{}_{\theta}{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(q_{\theta}).

Say we have fixed on some such Î¸ğœƒ\theta-estimation procedure to run at the end of the algorithm. The final step of each iteration of immediate sampling is to run Î·ğœ‚\eta, the map taking the samples generated so far to a new hâ„h. Ideally, we want to use the Î·ğœ‚\eta that, when repeatedly run during the algorithm, maximizes the expected accuracy of the final Î¸ğœƒ\theta-estimation. However even for a simple Î¸ğœƒ\theta-estimation procedure, determining this optimal Î·ğœ‚\eta can be quite difficult. As discussed later, it is identical to the active learning problem in machine learning.

In this paper we adopt a two-step heuristic for setting Î·ğœ‚\eta. In the first step, at the end of each iteration, we estimate the optimal qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} based on all the sample sets generated so far, using Eq.Â 15. In the second step, we complete Î·ğœ‚\eta by setting the new hâ„h to the current estimate of the optimal qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta}. At that point, the new hâ„h is used to generate a new sample set, and the process repeats.

4.3 Immediate Sampling with MCMC

For certain types of â„±ğ’¢subscriptâ„±ğ’¢{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}, it is possible to form samples using other sampling methods like Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC)Â (see Mackay, 2003; Bernardo and Smith, 2000; Berger, 1985). For example, if â„±ğ’¢â€‹(Î¸)subscriptâ„±ğ’¢ğœƒ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta) is pâ€‹qğ‘ğ‘pq distance from the Boltzmann distribution pÎ²superscriptğ‘ğ›½p^{\beta} to qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta}, then we can use MCMC to form a sample set of pÎ²superscriptğ‘ğ›½p^{\beta} (not of qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta}). We can then use that sample set to form an unbiased estimate of â„±ğ’¢â€‹(Î¸)subscriptâ„±ğ’¢ğœƒ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta) for any Î¸ğœƒ\theta. But if Î²ğ›½\beta were to change, these old samples cannot be used directly. One would have to resort to additional techniques like rejection sampling in order to reuse these samples. The advantage of using importance sampling is that all previous samples can be reused by the simple expedient of modifying their likelihood ratios. Therefore, in this paper, we only consider sampling distributions hâ„h that can be sampled directly, without any need for techniques like MCMC.

4.4 Advantages of Immediate-Sampling PC

In contrast to delayed sampling, immediate sampling usually presents no difficulty with reusing old data, as shown above; all (xi,j,gi,j)superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘—(x^{i,j},g^{i,j}) pairs can be used directly. Note that we can also reuse data that was generated when Fğ¹F was different, for instance, data generated under a differerent Î²isuperscriptğ›½ğ‘–\beta^{i} during a KL distance minimization procedure. As long as we store hjâ€‹(xi,j)superscriptâ„ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘—h^{j}(x^{i,j}) in addition to gi,jsuperscriptğ‘”ğ‘–ğ‘—g^{i,j} and xi,jsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘—x^{i,j} for every sample, we can always evaluate rhji,jâ€‹(xi,j,Î¸)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptâ„ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœƒr^{i,j}_{h^{j}}(x^{i,j},\theta) for any Fğ¹F.

Indeed, we can even comment on optimal ways of reusing this old data. Since each rhji,jâ€‹(xi,j,Î¸)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptâ„ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœƒr^{i,j}_{h^{j}}(x^{i,j},\theta) is an unbiased estimate of the integral â„±ğ’¢â€‹(Î¸)subscriptâ„±ğ’¢ğœƒ{\mathscr{F}}_{\mathscr{G}}(\theta), any weighted average of the rhji,jâ€‹(xi,j,Î¸)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptâ„ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœƒr^{i,j}_{h^{j}}(x^{i,j},\theta)â€™s is also an unbiased estimate. This can be exploited in the Î¸ğœƒ\theta-estimation procedure. For instance, consider the estimator of Eq.Â 15. If we have good estimates of the variances of the individual rhji,jâ€‹(xi,j,Î¸)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptâ„ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœƒr^{i,j}_{h^{j}}(x^{i,j},\theta), we can weight the terms rhji,jâ€‹(xi,j,Î¸)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptâ„ğ‘—superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğ‘—ğœƒr^{i,j}_{h^{j}}(x^{i,j},\theta) to minimize the variance of the associated weighted average estimator. Those weights are proportional to the inverses of the variancesÂ (see Macready and Wolpert, 2005; Lepage, 1978, 1980). As discussed in Sec.Â 2.3, the accuracy of the associated MCO algorithm could be expected to improve under such weighting.

We can also shed light on how to go about gathering new data. As in the VEGAS AlgorithmÂ (Lepage, 1978, 1980), one could incorporate bias-variance considerations into the operator Î·ğœ‚\eta that sets the next sampling distribution. To give an example, let ÎÎ\Xi be the range of Î·ğœ‚\eta, and fix Î¸ğœƒ\theta. Given ÎÎ\Xi and Î¸ğœƒ\theta, one can ask what proposal distribution hâˆˆÎâ„Îh\in\Xi would minimize the sample variance of the estimator in Eq.Â 14. Intuitively, this is akin to asking how best to do active learning. In general, the answer to this question, the optimal sampling distribution hâ€‹(x)â„ğ‘¥h(x), will be set by the function rPâ€‹(gâˆ£x,ğ’¢),hâ€‹(Î¸)subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘”ğ‘¥ğ’¢â„ğœƒr_{P(g\mid x,{\mathscr{G}}),h}(\theta), viewed as mapping Xâ†’â„â†’ğ‘‹â„X\rightarrow{\mathbb{R}}. Accordingly, for any fixed Î¸ğœƒ\theta, one can use the MC samples generated so far to estimate the xğ‘¥x-dependence of rPâ€‹(gâˆ£x,ğ’¢),hâ€‹(Î¸)subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘”ğ‘¥ğ’¢â„ğœƒr_{P(g\mid x,{\mathscr{G}}),h}(\theta), and thereby estimate the optimal hâˆˆÎâ„Îh\in\Xi. One then uses that estimate as the next sampling distribution hâ„h.

Another advantage of immediate sampling over delayed sampling is that the analysis in delayed sampling relies crucially on the parametrization of the qğ‘qâ€™s; some such parametrizations will permit the closed-form calculations of delayed sampling, and others will not. In immediate sampling, this problem disappears.

4.5 Implications of the Identity Between MCO and PL

For the case where â„±ğ’¢â€‹(Î¸)subscriptâ„±ğ’¢ğœƒ{\mathscr{F}}_{{\mathscr{G}}}(\theta) is an integral transform like Eq.Â 9, the PC optimization problem (P5) becomes a special case of minimizing a parametrized integral, the problem (P2). Formally, the equivalence is made by equating xğ‘¥x with the parameter Ï•italic-Ï•\phi, gğ‘”g with wğ‘¤w, and gÃ—Pâ€‹(gâˆ£x,ğ’¢)ğ‘”ğ‘ƒconditionalğ‘”ğ‘¥ğ’¢g\times P(g\mid x,{\mathscr{G}}) with Uâ€‹(w,Ï•)ğ‘ˆğ‘¤italic-Ï•U(w,\phi). In particular, immediate sampling is a special case of MCO. This identity means that we can exploit the extremely well-researched field of PL to improve many aspects of immediate sampling. In particular:

  • â€¢

    PL techniques like boostingÂ (Schapire and Singer, 1999) and baggingÂ (Breiman, 1994) can be used in (re)using old samples before forming new ones.

  • â€¢

    Variants of active learning101010Active learning in the precise machine learning sense uses current data to decide on a new query xğ‘¥x to feed to the oracle. We use the term more loosely here, to refer to any scheme for using current data to dynamically modify a process for generating for future queries. can be used to set and update hâ„h. Some aspect of this are discussed in Sec.Â 6 below.

  • â€¢

    Cross-validation is directly applicable in many ways: In our context, the curse of dimensionality arises if ğ’¬ğ’¬{\mathscr{Q}} is very large. We can address this the conventional PL way, by adding a regularization function of qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} to the objective function. The parameters controlling this regularization can be updated dynamically, as new data is generated, using cross-validation

    To use cross-validation this way, one forms multiple partitions of the current data. For each such partition, one calculates the optimal qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} for the training subset of that partition. One then examines error on the validation subset of that partition. More precisely, one calculates the unregularized objective value on the held-out data.

  • â€¢

    More generally, we can use cross-validation to dynamically update any parameters of the immediate sampling algorithm. For example, we can update the â€˜temperatureâ€™ parameter Î²ğ›½\beta of the Boltzmann distribution, arising in both qâ€‹pğ‘ğ‘qp and pâ€‹qğ‘ğ‘pq KL distance, this way.

    Note that doing this does not involve making more calls to the oracle.

  • â€¢

    We can also use cross-validation to choose the best model class (parametrization) for qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta}, among several candidates.

  • â€¢

    As an alternative to all these uses of cross-validation, one can use stacking to dynamically combine differrent temperatures, different parametrized density functions, and so on.

  • â€¢

    One may also be able to apply kernel methods to do the density estimationÂ (see Macready, 2005).

5 Experiments

In this section, we demonstrate the application of PL and immediate-sampling PC techniques to the unconstrained optimization of continuous functions, both deterministic and nondeterministic. We first describe our choice of â„±ğ’¢subscriptâ„±ğ’¢\mathscr{F}_{\mathscr{G}}, in this case pâ€‹qğ‘ğ‘pq KL distance. Next, as an illustrative example, we apply immediate sampling to the simplest of optimization problems, where the objective is a 2-D quadratic. Subsequently, we apply it to deterministic and stochastic versions of two well-known unconstrained optimization benchmarks, the Rosenbrock function and the Woods function.

We highlight the use of PL techniques to enhance optimizer performance on these benchmark problems. In particular, we show that cross-validation for regularization yields a performance improvement of an order of magnitude. We then show that cross-validation for model-selection results in improved performance, especially in the early stages of the algorithm. We also show that bagging can yield significant improvements in performance.

5.1 Minimizing pâ€‹qğ‘ğ‘pq KL Distance

Recall that the integral form of pâ€‹qğ‘ğ‘pq KL distance is

It is easy to show that when there are no restrictions on qğ‘q being a parametrized density, pâ€‹qğ‘ğ‘pq KL distance is minimized if p=qğ‘ğ‘p=q. 5.1.3 Mixture Models

The single Gaussian is a fairly restrictive class of models. Mixture models can significantly improve flexibility, but at the cost of convexity of the KL distance minimization problem. However, a plethora of techniques from supervized learning, in particular the Expectation Maximization (EM) algorithm, can be applied with minor modifications.

Suppose qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} is a mixture of Mğ‘€M Gaussians, that is, Î¸=(Î¼,Î£,Ï•)ğœƒğœ‡Î£italic-Ï•\theta=(\mu,\Sigma,\phi) where Ï•italic-Ï•\phi is the mixing p.m.f, we can view the problem as one where a hidden variable zğ‘§z decides which mixture component each sample is drawn from. We then have the optimization problem

minimizeÂ âˆ’âˆ‘Dpâ€‹(xi)hâ€‹(xi)â€‹lnâ¡(qÎ¸â€‹(xi,zi)).minimizeÂ subscriptğ·ğ‘superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–â„superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptğ‘§ğ‘–\textrm{minimize }-\sum_{D}\displaystyle\frac{p(x^{i})}{h(x^{i})}\ln\left(q_{\theta}(x^{i},z^{i})\right).

Following the standard EM procedure, we multiply and divide the quantity inside the logarithm by some Qiâ€‹(zi)subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–superscriptğ‘§ğ‘–Q_{i}(z^{i}), where Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{i} is a distribution over the possible values of zisuperscriptğ‘§ğ‘–z^{i}. As before, let sisuperscriptğ‘ ğ‘–s^{i} be the likelihood ratio of the iğ‘–iâ€™th sample.

minimizeÂ âˆ’âˆ‘Dsiâ€‹lnâ¡(âˆ‘ziQiâ€‹(zi)â€‹qÎ¸â€‹(xi,zi)Qiâ€‹(zi))minimizeÂ subscriptğ·superscriptğ‘ ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘§ğ‘–subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–superscriptğ‘§ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğœƒsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptğ‘§ğ‘–subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–superscriptğ‘§ğ‘–\textrm{minimize }-\sum_{D}\displaystyle s^{i}\ln\left(\sum_{z^{i}}Q_{i}(z^{i})\frac{q_{\theta}(x^{i},z^{i})}{Q_{i}(z^{i})}\right)

Then using Jensenâ€™s inequality, we can take Qisubscriptğ‘„ğ‘–Q_{i} outside the logarithm to get a lower bound. To make this lower bound tight, choose Qiâ€‹(zi)subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–superscriptğ‘§ğ‘–Q_{i}(z^{i}) to be the constant pâ€‹(zi|xi)ğ‘conditionalsuperscriptğ‘§ğ‘–superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–p(z^{i}|x^{i}). Finally, differentiating with respect to Î¼j,Î£jâˆ’1subscriptğœ‡ğ‘—subscriptsuperscriptÎ£1ğ‘—\mu_{j},\Sigma^{-1}_{j} and Ï•jsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘—\phi_{j} gives us the EM-like algorithm:

Since this is a nonconvex problem, one typically runs the algorithm multiple times with random initializations of the parameters.

An overview of the procedure is presented in AlgorithmÂ 1.

5.2.5 Bagging

While regularization is a method to decrease bias, bagging is a well-known variance-reducing technique. Bagging is easily incorporated in our algorithm. Suppose, at some stage in the algorithm, we have Nğ‘N samples (xi,gi)superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptğ‘”ğ‘–(x^{i},g^{i}), we resample our existing data set exactly Nğ‘N times with replacement. This gives us a different set of data set Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime}, which also contains some duplicates. We compute optimal parameters Î¸â‹†â€‹(Dâ€²)superscriptğœƒâ‹†superscriptğ·â€²\theta^{\star}(D^{\prime}). We repeat this resampling process kbsubscriptğ‘˜ğ‘k_{b} times and uniformly average the resulting optimal densities qÎ¸â‹†â€‹(Dkâ€²),k=1,â€¦,kbformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘superscriptğœƒâ‹†subscriptsuperscriptğ·â€²ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1â€¦subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘q_{\theta^{\star}(D^{\prime}_{k})},k=1,\ldots,k_{b}.

We demonstrate this procedure, using the Rosenbrock function and a single Gaussian qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta}. In this experiment, we also demonstrate the ability of PC to handle non-deterministic oracles by adding uniform random noise to every function evaluation, that is, (gâˆ£x,G)âˆ¼ğ’°â€‹[âˆ’0.25,0.25]similar-toconditionalğ‘”ğ‘¥ğºğ’°0.250.25(g\mid x,G)\sim\mathcal{U}[-0.25,0.25]. For this experiment, Nj=20,kb=5formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ğ‘—20subscriptğ‘˜ğ‘5N_{j}=20,k_{b}=5. The Î²ğ›½\beta update is performed using the same cross-validation algorithm described above. Fig.Â 6 shows the results of 50 runs of the PC algorithm with and without bagging.

We see that bagging finds better solutions, and moreover, it reduces the variance between runs. Note that the way we use bagging, we are only assured of improved variance for a single MC estimation at a given Î¸ğœƒ\theta, and not over the whole MCO process of searching over Î¸ğœƒ\theta.

5.2.6 Cross-validation for Regularization and Model Selection

In many problems like the Rosenbrock, a single Gaussian is a poor fit to pÎ²superscriptğ‘ğ›½p^{\beta} for many values of Î²ğ›½\beta. In these cases, we can use a mixture of Gaussians to obtain a better fit to pÎ²superscriptğ‘ğ›½p^{\beta}. We now describe the use of cross-validation to pick the number of components in the mixture model. We use an algorithm very similar to the one described for regularization. In these experiments, we use a greedy algorithm to search over the joint space of Î²ğ›½\beta and models:

  1. 1.

    We first pick the regularization parameter Î²ğ›½\beta, using AlgorithmÂ 2.

  2. 2.

    For that Î²ğ›½\beta, we use AlgorithmÂ 3 to pick the number of mixture components.

For this experiment, the details are the same as the preceding section, but without bagging. The set of models {{Ï•}}italic-Ï•\{\{\phi\}\} is the set of Gaussian mixtures with one, two or three mixing components. Fig.Â 7 shows the variation of ğ”¼qâ€‹(G)subscriptğ”¼ğ‘ğº\mathbb{E}_{q}(G) vs. iteration.

The mixture model is much quicker to yield lower expected G, because the Boltzmann at many values of Î²ğ›½\beta is better approximated by a mixture of Gaussians. However, note that the mixture models performs poorly towards the end of the run. The reason for this is as follows: No shape regularization was used during the EM procedure. This means that the algorithm often samples from nearly degenerate Gaussians. These â€˜strangeâ€™ sample sets hurt the subsequent performance of importance sampling, and hence of the associated MCO problem. This can be alleviated by using some form of shape regularization in the EM algorithm.

6 Fit-based Monte Carlo

Thus far, we have not exploited the locations of the samples in constructing esimates. In this section, we discuss the incorporation of sample locations to improve both MC and MCO.

6.1 Fit-based MC Estimation of Integrals

We first consider MC estimation of an integral, presented at the beginning of Sec.Â 2.3. Recall from that discussion, that to accord with MCO notation, we write the integral to be estimated as â„’â€‹(Ï•)=âˆ«ğ‘‘wâ€‹Uâ€‹(w,Ï•)â„’italic-Ï•differential-dğ‘¤ğ‘ˆğ‘¤italic-Ï•{\mathscr{L}}(\phi)=\int dw\;U(w,\phi) for some fixed Ï•italic-Ï•\phi. In this notation the sampling of vğ‘£v provides a sample set {(wi,Uâ€‹(wi,Ï•)):i=1,â€¦â€‹N)delimited-{):superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–italic-Ï•ğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘\{(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi)):i=1,\ldots N). The associated sum â„’^{(wi,Uâ€‹(wi,Ï•))}â‰¡â„’^â€‹(Ï•)subscript^â„’superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–italic-Ï•^â„’italic-Ï•{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi))\}}\equiv{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) then serves as our estimate of the integral â„’â‰¡â„’â€‹(Ï•)â„’â„’italic-Ï•{\mathscr{L}}\equiv{\mathscr{L}}(\phi).

In forming the estimate â„’^{(wi,Uâ€‹(wi,Ï•))}subscript^â„’superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–italic-Ï•{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi))\}} we do not exploit the relationships between the locations of the sample points and the associated values of the integrand. Indeed, since those locations {wisuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–w^{i}} do not appear directly in that estimate, â„’^{(wi,Uâ€‹(wi,Ï•))}subscript^â„’superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–italic-Ï•{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi))\}} is unchanged even if those locations changed in such a way that the values {risuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r^{i}} stayed the same.

The idea behind fit-based (FB) Monte Carlo is to leverage the location data to replace â„’^{(wi,Uâ€‹(wi,Ï•))}subscript^â„’superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–italic-Ï•{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi))\}} with a more accurate estimate of â„’â„’\mathscr{L}. The most straightforward FB MC treats the sample pairs {(wi,U(wi,Ï•)):i=1,â€¦N)(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi)):i=1,\ldots N)} as a training set for a supervised-learning algorithm. Running such an algorithm produces a fit U~(.,Ï•){\tilde{U}}(.,\phi) taking wğ‘¤wâ€™s into â„â„\mathbb{R}. This fit is an estimate of the actual oracle U(,Ï•)U(,\phi), and this fit defines an estimate for the full integral,

â„’~{wi,Uâ€‹(wi,Ï•)}â‰¡âˆ«ğ‘‘wâ€‹U~â€‹(w,Ï•)subscript~â„’superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–italic-Ï•differential-dğ‘¤~ğ‘ˆğ‘¤italic-Ï•\displaystyle{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi)\}}\equiv\int dw\;{\tilde{U}}(w,\phi) (19)

We will sometimes omit the subscript and just write â„’~â€‹(Ï•)~â„’italic-Ï•{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) or even just â„’~~â„’{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}. In this most straightforward version of FB MC, we use â„’~~â„’{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}} as our estimate of â„’â„’\mathscr{L} rather than â„’^^â„’{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}.

In some circumstances one can evaluate â„’~~â„’{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}} in closed form. A recent paper reviewing some work on how to do this with Gaussian processes is given byÂ Rasmussen and Gharamani (2003). In other circumstances one can form low-order approximations to â„’â„’{\mathscr{L}}, for example using Laplace approximationsÂ (see Robert and Casella, 2004). Alternatively, conventional deterministic grid-based approximation of the integral â„’â„’{\mathscr{L}} can be cast as a degenerate version of closed-form fit-based estimation131313To see this, modify the MC process to be sampling without replacement. Choose the proposal distribution vğ‘£v for this process to be a sum of delta functions. The centers of those delta functions give the points on a regular grid of points in the space of allowed xğ‘¥xâ€™s. Have the number of samples equal the number of such grid points. Finally, have our fit to the samples, U~(.,Ï•){\tilde{U}}(.,\phi), be a sum of step-wise constant functions, going through the sample points. The closed form integral of that fit given by Eq.Â 19 is just the Reimann approximation to the original integral, âˆ«ğ‘‘wâ€‹Uâ€‹(w,Ï•)differential-dğ‘¤ğ‘ˆğ‘¤italic-Ï•\int dw\;U(w,\phi). of â„’â„’{\mathscr{L}}.

More generally, one can form an approximation to the integral â„’~â€‹(Ï•)~â„’italic-Ï•{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) by MC sampling of U~(.,Ï•){\tilde{U}}(.,\phi). Generating these fictitious samples of U~(.,Ï•)\tilde{U}(.,\phi) does not incur the expense of calling the actual oracle U(.,Ï•)U(.,\phi). So, in this approach, we run MC twice. The first time, we generate the factual samples {(wi,U(wi,Ï•)):i=1,â€¦N)(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi)):i=1,\ldots N)}. Given those samples, we form the fit to them, U~(.,Ï•)\tilde{U}(.,\phi). We then run a second MC process using the fictitious oracle U~(.,Ï•)\tilde{U}(.,\phi).

Note that in all of these approaches, the original sampling distribution vğ‘£v does not directly arise, that is, the values {vâ€‹(wi)ğ‘£superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–v(w^{i})} do not arise. In particular, if one were to change those values without changing the factual sample locations {wi}superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–\{w^{i}\}, then the estimate â„’~{(wi,Uâ€‹(wi,Ï•))}subscript~â„’superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–italic-Ï•{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi))\}} would not change. Of course, a different vğ‘£v would result in a different sample set, and thereby a different estimate, but given a sample set, the sampling distribution is immaterial. This is typically the case with FB MC estimators, and it contrasts with the estimator â„’^{(wi,Uâ€‹(wi,Ï•))}subscript^â„’superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–italic-Ï•{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{(w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi))\}}, which would change if vğ‘£v were changed without changing the factual sample locations.

Note also that the factual samples underlying the fit U~(.,Ï•){\tilde{U}}(.,\phi) are exact samples of the factual oracle, U(.,Ï•)U(.,\phi). In contrast, since in general U~(.,Ï•)â‰ U(.,Ï•){\tilde{U}}(.,\phi)\neq U(.,\phi), the fictitious samples will be erroneous, if viewed as samples of U(.,Ï•)U(.,\phi). Since we are ultimately concerned with an integral of U(.,Ï•)U(.,\phi), this suggests that the fictitious samples should be weighted less than the factual samples. This might be the case even if one had infinitely many fictitious samples. In fact, even if one could evaluate â„’~~â„’{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}} in closed form, it might make sense not to use it directly as our final estimate of â„’â„’{\mathscr{L}}. Instead, combining it with the importance-sampling estimate â„’^^â„’{\hat{\mathscr{L}}} might improve the estimate.

6.2 Bayesian Fit-based MCO

We now extend the discussion to MCO by allowing Ï•italic-Ï•\phi to vary. As with the case of FB MC estimation of an integral, the most straightforward version of FB MCO uses â„’~â€‹(Ï•)~â„’italic-Ï•{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) rather than â„’^â€‹(Ï•)^â„’italic-Ï•{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) as our estimate of â„’â€‹(Ï•)â„’italic-Ï•{\mathscr{L}}(\phi). This means that we use argmin[â„’~(Ï•)]Ï•{}_{\phi}[{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi)] rather than argmin[â„’^(Ï•)]Ï•{}_{\phi}[{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi)] as our estimate of the Ï•italic-Ï•\phi optimizing â„’â€‹(Ï•)â„’italic-Ï•{\mathscr{L}}(\phi).

â„’^â€‹(Ï•)^â„’italic-Ï•{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) is a sum, whereas â„’~â€‹(Ï•)~â„’italic-Ï•{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) is an integral. This means that different algorithms are required to find the Ï•italic-Ï•\phi optimizing them. Indeed, optimizing â„’~â€‹(Ï•)~â„’italic-Ï•{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) is formally the same type of problem as optimizing â„’â€‹(Ï•)â„’italic-Ï•{\mathscr{L}}(\phi); both functions of Ï•italic-Ï•\phi are parametrized integrals over wğ‘¤w. So if needed, we can use PLMCO techniques to optimize â„’~â€‹(Ï•)~â„’italic-Ï•{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi). Again, as with MC, the integrand of â„’~â€‹(Ï•)~â„’italic-Ï•{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) is not the factual oracle. So, minimizing â„’~â€‹(Ï•)~â„’italic-Ï•{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}(\phi) using PLMCO sampling techniques will not require making additional calls to the factual oracle.

Consider a Bayesian approach to forming the fit. Our problem is to solve the MCO problem (P2), given that the factual oracle Uğ‘ˆU is not known, and we only can generate samples of Uğ‘ˆU. Adopting a fully Bayesian perspective, since Uğ‘ˆU is not known, we must treat it as a random variable. So we have a posterior distribution over all possible oracles, reflecting all the data we have concerning the factual oracle. We then use that posterior to try to solve (P2).

Say that in the usual way that our data contains the wğ‘¤wâ€™s and the associated functions U(w,.)U(w,.) of a sample set that was generated by importance sampling Uğ‘ˆU (see Sec.Â 2). More generally, we may have additional data, for instance, the gradients of Uğ‘ˆU at the sample points. For simplicity though, we restrict attention to the case where the provided information is only the sample set of functions, {wi,ri(.)}\{w^{i},r^{i}(.)\}, together with vğ‘£v.

We will use Dğ·D to refer to a sample set for MC or MCO, and for immediate sampling in particular. So we write our posterior over oracles141414Practically, when running a computer experiment, Uğ‘ˆU is the actual oracle generating Dğ·D according to a likelihood P(Dâˆ£UP(D\mid U). On the other hand, the posterior Pâ€‹(Ucâˆ£D)ğ‘ƒconditionalsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘ğ·P(U_{c}\mid D) reflects both that likelihood and a prior Pâ€‹(Uc)ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘P(U_{c}) assumed by the algorithm. So, Ucsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘U_{c} is a random variable, whereas Uğ‘ˆU refers to the single true factual oracle. as Pâ€‹(Ucâˆ£D)ğ‘ƒconditionalsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘ğ·P(U_{c}\mid D). Using this notation, the goal in Bayesian FB MCO is to exploit Pâ€‹(Ucâˆ£D)ğ‘ƒconditionalsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘ğ·P(U_{c}\mid D) to improve our estimate of the Ï•italic-Ï•\phi that minimizes âˆ«ğ‘‘wâ€‹Uâ€‹(w,Ï•)differential-dğ‘¤ğ‘ˆğ‘¤italic-Ï•\int dw\;U(w,\phi).

How should we use Pâ€‹(Ucâˆ£D)ğ‘ƒconditionalsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘ğ·P({U_{c}}\mid D) to estimate the solution to (P2)? Bayesian decision theory tells us to minimize posterior expected loss, âˆ«ğ‘‘Ucâ€‹Pâ€‹(Ucâˆ£D)â€‹Lâ€‹(Ï•,Uc)differential-dsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘ğ‘ƒconditionalsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘ğ·ğ¿italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘\int d{U_{c}}\;P({U_{c}}\mid D)L(\phi,{U_{c}}). Given the loss function of Eq.Â 4, that means we wish to solve

(P6):Â â€‹minÏ•â€‹âˆ«ğ‘‘Ucâ€‹Pâ€‹(Ucâˆ£D)â€‹Lâ€‹(Ï•,Uc)(P6):Â subscriptitalic-Ï•differential-dsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘ğ‘ƒconditionalsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘ğ·ğ¿italic-Ï•subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘\displaystyle\textrm{(P6): }\min_{\phi}\int d{U_{c}}\;P({U_{c}}\mid D)L(\phi,{U_{c}}) =\displaystyle= minÏ•â€‹âˆ«ğ‘‘wcâ€‹ğ‘‘Ucâ€‹Pâ€‹(Ucâˆ£D)â€‹Ucâ€‹(wc,Ï•).subscriptitalic-Ï•differential-dsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘differential-dsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘ğ‘ƒconditionalsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘ğ·subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘italic-Ï•\displaystyle\min_{\phi}\int dw_{c}d{U_{c}}\;P({U_{c}}\mid D){U_{c}}(w_{c},\phi).

To solve (P6) with PLMCO one generates fictitious samples by sampling one distribution over Ucsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘{U_{c}}â€™s and one over wcsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘w_{c}â€™s. 6.3 Example: Fit-based Immediate Sampling

To illustrate the foregoing we consider the variant of MCO given by immediate sampling with a noise-free oracle. In the simple version of MCO considered just above, the estimate we make for Ï•italic-Ï•\phi has no effect on what points are chosen for any future calls we might make to the oracle. For simplicity, we restrict attention to the analogous formulation of immediate sampling. Using immediate sampling terminology, this means that we only consider the issue of how best to estimate Î¸ğœƒ\theta after the immediate sampling algorithm has exhausted all its calls to the oracle. We do not consider the more general active learning issue, of how best to estimate Î¸ğœƒ\theta when this estimate will be affect further calls to the oracle. However see Sec.Â 6.6 below.

However we arrive at our (estimated) optimal qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta}, most simplistically, we can update hâ„h to equal that new qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta}. In a more sophisticated approach, we could set hâ„h from the sample functions using active learning (see Sec.Â 6.6 below). Once we have that new hâ„h we can form samples of it to generate new factual sample locations xğ‘¥x. These in turn are fed to the factual oracle GğºG to augment our data set Dğ·D. Then the process repeats.

Note that unlike with non-FB immediate sampling, with FB immediate sampling we need to evaluate Pâ€‹(Gcâˆ£D)ğ‘ƒconditionalsubscriptğºğ‘ğ·P({G_{c}}\mid D) (or sample it, if we choose to have Hâ€‹(Gc)â‰œPâ€‹(Gcâˆ£D)â‰œğ»subscriptğºğ‘ğ‘ƒconditionalsubscriptğºğ‘ğ·H({G_{c}})\triangleq P({G_{c}}\mid D)). This may be non-trivial. On the other hand, that very same distribution Pâ€‹(Gcâˆ£D)ğ‘ƒconditionalsubscriptğºğ‘ğ·P({G_{c}}\mid D) that may cause difficulty also gives the major advantage of the fit-based approach; it allows any insights we have into how to fit a curve Gcsubscriptğºğ‘{G_{c}} to the data points Dğ·D to be exploited.

6.4 Exploiting FB Immediate Sampling

To illustrate how fitting might improve immediate sampling, consider the case where â„±Gâ€‹(qÎ¸)subscriptâ„±ğºsubscriptğ‘ğœƒ{\mathscr{F}}_{G}(q_{\theta}) is qâ€‹pğ‘ğ‘qp KL distance. Say that Gâ€‹(x)ğºğ‘¥G(x) is a high-dimensional convex paraboloid inside a hypercube, and zero outside of that hypercube. Suppose as well that we have a single factual sampling distribution hâ„h, which is concentrated on one side of the paraboloid. For example, if the peak of the paraboloid is at the origin, hâ„h might be a Gaussian (masked by the hypercube) whose mean lies several sigmas away from the origin.

To start, consider importance sampling MC estimation of the integral â„±Gâ€‹(qÎ¸)subscriptâ„±ğºsubscriptğ‘ğœƒ{\mathscr{F}}_{G}(q_{\theta}) for one particular Î¸ğœƒ\theta, without any concern about choosing among Î¸ğœƒ\thetaâ€™s. Say that the factual sample Dğ·D isnâ€™t too large. Then it is likely that no elements of Dğ·D are in regions where GğºG reaches its lowest values. For such a Dğ·D, the associated factual estimate

â„±^Dâ€‹(Î¸)subscript^â„±ğ·ğœƒ\displaystyle{\hat{\mathscr{F}}}_{D}(\theta) â‰œâ‰œ\displaystyle\triangleq âˆ‘irhiâ€‹(xi,Î¸)Nsubscriptğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–â„superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–ğœƒğ‘\displaystyle\frac{\sum_{i}r^{i}_{h}(x^{i},\theta)}{N} (27)

is larger than the actual value, â„±Gâ€‹(qÎ¸)subscriptâ„±ğºsubscriptğ‘ğœƒ{\mathscr{F}}_{G}(q_{\theta}) (cf. Eq.Â 14). So straightforward importance-sampling integral estimation is likely to be badly off.202020Since importance sampling is unbiased, this means its variance is likely to be large.

Intuitively, the problem is that as far as the factual estimate â„±^Dâ€‹(Î¸)subscript^â„±ğ·ğœƒ{\hat{\mathscr{F}}}_{D}(\theta) is concerned, GğºG could just as well be a sum of delta functions centered at the xğ‘¥xâ€™s in Dğ·D, with low associated oracle sample values, as a paraboloid. If GğºG were in fact such a sum, then â„±^Dsubscript^â„±ğ·{\hat{\mathscr{F}}}_{D} would be correct. However by looking at the (x,Gâ€‹(x))ğ‘¥ğºğ‘¥(x,G(x)) pairs in Dğ·D, all of which lie on the same paraboloid, such an inference of GğºG appears quite unreasonable. It makes sense to instead infer that GğºG is a paraboloid.

Fitting is a way to formalize (and exploit) such Dğ·D-based insights. As an example, consider using a Bayesian PL algorithm to do the fitting. Typical choices for the prior Pâ€‹(Gc)ğ‘ƒsubscriptğºğ‘P({G_{c}}) used in PL would result in a posterior Pâ€‹(Gcâˆ£D)ğ‘ƒconditionalsubscriptğºğ‘ğ·P({G_{c}}\mid{D}) that would be far more tightly concentrated about the actual GğºGâ€™s paraboloid shape than about the sum of delta functions. Fitting would automatically reflect this, and thereby produce a better estimate of â„±Gâ€‹(Î¸)subscriptâ„±ğºğœƒ{\mathscr{F}}_{G}(\theta) than â„±^Dâ€‹(Î¸)subscript^â„±ğ·ğœƒ{\hat{\mathscr{F}}}_{D}(\theta).212121It might be objected that in a different problem GğºG actually would be the sum of delta functions, not the paraboloid. In that case the FB estimate is the one that would be in error. However this possibility is exactly what the prior Pâ€‹(Gc)ğ‘ƒsubscriptğºğ‘P({G_{c}}) addresses; if in fact you have reason to believe that a GğºG that is a sum of delta functions is a priori just as likely as a paraboloid GğºG, then that should be reflected in Pâ€‹(Gc)ğ‘ƒsubscriptğºğ‘P({G_{c}}). Doing so would in turn make the FB estimate more closely track the non-FB estimate.

Now we arenâ€™t directly concerned with the accuracy of our estimate â„±Gâ€‹(qÎ¸)subscriptâ„±ğºsubscriptğ‘ğœƒ{\mathscr{F}}_{G}(q_{\theta}) for any single Î¸ğœƒ\theta. We arenâ€™t even concerned with the overall accuracy of that estimate for a set of Î¸ğœƒ\thetaâ€™s. Rather we are concerned with the accuracy of the ranking of the Î¸ğœƒ\thetaâ€™s given by those estimates. For example, consider naive MCO, under which we choose the Î¸ğœƒ\theta minimizing â„±~Dâ€‹(Î¸)subscript~â„±ğ·ğœƒ{\tilde{\mathscr{F}}}_{D}(\theta). Even if all of our estimates (one for each Î¸ğœƒ\theta) were far from the associated actual values, if their signed errors were identical, the naive MCO would perform perfectly.

In other words, ultimately we are interested in correlations between errors of our estimates of â„±Gâ€‹(qÎ¸)subscriptâ„±ğºsubscriptğ‘ğœƒ{\mathscr{F}}_{G}(q_{\theta}) for different Î¸ğœƒ\thetaâ€™s. (See Sec.Â 2.3.) Nonetheless, we might expect that if we tend to have large error in our estimates of â„±Gâ€‹(qÎ¸)subscriptâ„±ğºsubscriptğ‘ğœƒ{\mathscr{F}}_{G}(q_{\theta}) for the Î¸ğœƒ\thetaâ€™s, then everything else being equal, we would be likely to have large error in the associated estimate of an optimal Î¸ğœƒ\theta.

In Sec.Â 4.5 we exploited the equivalence between PL and MCO to improve upon naive MCO. However the parameter in MCO doesnâ€™t specify a functional fit to a data set. Accordingly, the incorporation of PL into MCO considered in Sec.Â 4.5 doesnâ€™t involve fitting a function to Dğ·D. This is why those PLMCO techniques donâ€™t address the issue raised in this example; fitting does that. So in full FB MCO, we may use PL in two separate parts of the algorithm, both to form the fit to Dğ·D, and then to use those fits to choose among the Î¸ğœƒ\thetaâ€™s.

6.5 Statistical Analysis of FB MC

Before analyzing expected performance of FB MCO, we start with the simpler case of FB MC introduced at the beginning of this section. For simplicity we assume that the integral â„’~Dsubscript~â„’ğ·{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D} can be calculated exactly for any Dğ·D, so that no fictitious samples arise.

As discussed in Sec.Â 2.3, two important properties of an MC estimator of an integral â„’â€‹(Ï•)=âˆ«ğ‘‘wâ€‹Uâ€‹(w,Ï•)â„’italic-Ï•differential-dğ‘¤ğ‘ˆğ‘¤italic-Ï•{\mathscr{L}}(\phi)=\int dw\;U(w,\phi) are the sample bias and the sample variance of that estimator. Together, these give the expected loss of the estimator under a quadratic loss function, conditioned on a fixed oracle U(.,Ï•)U(.,\phi).

This is just as true for a Bayesian fitting algorithm as for any other. For quadratic loss, for sample set Dâ‰¡{wi,Uâ€‹(wi,Ï•)}ğ·superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–italic-Ï•D\equiv\{w^{i},U(w^{i},\phi)\}, the Bayesian FB MC prediction for â„’â„’{\mathscr{L}} is the posterior mean,
