âˆ«dw1â€¦dwNâˆi=1Nv(wi)[âˆ«dwâ€²U(wâ€²,Ï•)âˆ’âˆ«dwâ€²dUc(,Ï•)Uc(wâ€²,Ï•)P(Uc(.,Ï•)âˆ£D)]2\displaystyle\int d{w}^{1}\ldots d{w}^{N}\;\prod_{i=1}^{N}v({w}^{i})[\int d{w}^{\prime}\;U({w}^{\prime},\phi)\;-\;\int d{w}^{\prime}\;dU_{c}(,\phi)\;U_{c}({w}^{\prime},\phi)P(U_{c}(.,\phi)\mid D)]^{2} (29)

where vğ‘£v is the proposal distribution that is IID sampled Nğ‘{N} times to generate the sample set.

In the usual way one can re-express this expected quadratic loss using a bias-variance decomposition. Whereas a conventional importance sample estimator of âˆ«ğ‘‘wâ€‹Uâ€‹(w,Ï•)differential-dğ‘¤ğ‘ˆğ‘¤italic-Ï•\int d{w}\;U(w,\phi) is unbiased, the Bayesian estimator is biased in general; typically

âˆ«dDP(Dâˆ£v,U(.,Ï•))â„’~D\displaystyle\int dD\;P(D\mid v,U(.,\phi))\;{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D} â‰ \displaystyle\neq â„’.â„’\displaystyle{\mathscr{L}}. (30)

This bias is a general characteristic of Bayesian estimators. Furthermore, for some functions U(.,Ï•)U(.,\phi), the Bayesian estimator will both be biased (unlike the factual sample estimator) and have higher variance than the factual sample estimator. So for those U(.,Ï•)U(.,\phi), the Bayesian estimator has worse bias plus variance.

In conventional importance sampling estimation of an integral, the sampling distribution vğ‘£v is used twice. First it is used to form the sample set. Then, when the sample set has been formed, vğ‘£v is used again, to set the denominator values in the ratios giving the MC estimate of the integral (cf. Sec.Â 2.2). In contrast, Bayesian FB MC doesnâ€™t care what vğ‘£v is. P(Uc(.,Ï•)âˆ£D)P(U_{c}(.,\phi)\mid D) is independent of the values vâ€‹(wi)ğ‘£superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–v({w}^{i}). As mentioned at the beginning of this section, this is a typical feature of FB MC estimators.

This feature does not mean that the sampling distribution is immaterial in FB MC however. Even though it does not arise in making the estimate, as Eq.Â 29 shows, vğ‘£v helps determine what the expected loss will be. Indeed, in principle at least, Eq.Â 29 can be used to guide the choice of the sampling distribution for Bayesian FB MC. It can even be used this way dynamically, at a midpoint of the sampling process, when one already has some samples of U(.,Ï•)U(.,\phi). Such a procedure for using Eq.Â 29 to set vğ‘£v dynamically amounts to what is called â€˜active learningâ€™ in the PL literatureÂ (see Freund etÂ al., 1997; Dasgupta and Kalai, 2005).

We now generalize the foregoing to the case of a non-quadratic loss function Lğ¿L. The Bayesian estimator produces the estimate

â„’~Dsubscript~â„’ğ·\displaystyle{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D} â‰œâ‰œ\displaystyle\triangleq argminÏâˆˆâ„[âˆ«dUc(.,Ï•)P(Uc(.,Ï•)âˆ£D)L[â„’~D,â„’Uc]]\displaystyle{\mbox{argmin}}_{\rho\in{\mathbb{R}}}[\int dU_{c}(.,\phi)\;P(U_{c}(.,\phi)\mid D)L[{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D},\;\;{\mathscr{L}}_{U_{c}}]] (31)

Given that the factual oracle is U(.,Ï•)U(.,\phi), the expected loss with that Bayesian estimator is

âˆ«ğ‘‘w1â€‹â€¦â€‹ğ‘‘wNâ€‹âˆi=1Nvâ€‹(wi)â€‹Lâ€‹[â„’~{wi,Uâ€‹(wi,Ï•)},âˆ«ğ‘‘wâ€²â€‹Uâ€‹(wâ€²,Ï•)].differential-dsuperscriptğ‘¤1â€¦differential-dsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘superscriptsubscriptproductğ‘–1ğ‘ğ‘£superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ¿subscript~â„’superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–italic-Ï•differential-dsuperscriptğ‘¤â€²ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘¤â€²italic-Ï•\displaystyle\int d{w}^{1}\ldots d{w}^{N}\;\prod_{i=1}^{N}v({w}^{i})L[{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{{w}^{i},U({w}^{i},\phi)\}},\;\;\int d{w}^{\prime}\;U({w}^{\prime},\phi)]. (32)

The expected loss in Eq.Â 32 is an average over data with the oracle held fixed. This contrasts with the analogous quantity typically considered in Bayesian analysis, which is an average over oracles with the data held fixed. That quantity is the posterior expected loss,

âˆ«dU(.,Ï•)P(U(.,Ï•)âˆ£D)L[â„’~D,â„’U(Ï•)]\displaystyle\int dU(.,\phi)P(U(.,\phi)\mid D)L[{{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D},\mathscr{L}}_{U}(\phi)] (33)

In general, different U(.,Ï•)U(.,\phi)â€™s will give different risks for the same estimator. So we can adapt any measure concerning loss in which U(.,Ï•)U(.,\phi) varies, to concern risk instead. In particular, the posterior expected risk is

âˆ«dU(.,Ï•)P(U(.,Ï•)âˆ£D){L[â„’~D,â„’U(Ï•)]âˆ’minÏâˆˆâ„[L[Ï,â„’U(Ï•)]]}.\displaystyle\int dU(.,\phi)P(U(.,\phi)\mid D)\;\{L[{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D},{\mathscr{L}}_{U}(\phi)]\;-\;{\mbox{min}}_{\rho\in{\mathbb{R}}}[L[\rho,{\mathscr{L}}_{U}(\phi)]]\}. (34)

Often the lower bound on loss is always 0, so that minÏâˆˆâ„[L[Ï,â„’U(Ï•)]]=0âˆ€U(.,Ï•){\mbox{min}}_{\rho\in{\mathbb{R}}}[L[\rho,{\mathscr{L}}_{U}(\phi)]]=0\;\forall\;U(.,\phi). In this case posterior expected risk just equals posterior expected loss.

We can combine the non-Bayesian and Bayesian analyses, involving expected loss and posterior expected loss respectively. To do this we consider the prior-averaged expected loss, given by

âˆ«dU(.,Ï•)P(U(.,Ï•))âˆ«dw1â€¦dwNâˆi=1Nv(wi)L[â„’~{(wi,Uâ€‹(wi,Ï•))},âˆ«dwâ€²U(wâ€²,Ï•)].\displaystyle\int dU(.,\phi)\;P(U(.,\phi))\int d{w}^{1}\ldots d{w}^{N}\;\prod_{i=1}^{N}v({w}^{i})L[{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{({w}^{i},U({w}^{i},\phi))\}},\;\int d{w}^{\prime}\;U({w}^{\prime},\phi)]. (35)

where P(U(.,Ï•))P(U(.,\phi)) is a prior distribution over oracles.

Note that the prior-averaged expected loss is an average over both oracles and sample sets. It reflects the following experimental test of our FB MCO algorithm: Multiple times a factual oracle U(.,Ï•)U(.,\phi) is generated by sampling P(U(.,Ï•))P(U(.,\phi)). For each such U(.,Ï•)U(.,\phi), many times a factual sample set Dğ·D is generated by sampling the likelihood P(Dâˆ£U(.,Ï•),v)P(D\mid U(.,\phi),v). That Dğ·D is then used by the FMCO algorithm to calculate â„’Dsubscriptâ„’ğ·{\mathscr{L}}_{D}. In performing that calculation, the algorithm assumes the same likelihood as was used to generate Dğ·D, but its prior P(Uc(.,Ï•))P(U_{c}(.,\phi)) may not be the same function of Uc(.,Ï•)U_{c}(.,\phi) as P(U(.,Ï•))P(U(.,\phi)) is of U(.,Ï•)U(.,\phi). Then the loss between â„’Dsubscriptâ„’ğ·{\mathscr{L}}_{D} and â„’Usubscriptâ„’ğ‘ˆ{\mathscr{L}}_{U} is calculated. The quantity in Eq.Â 35 is the average of that loss.

Say that P(U(.,Ï•))P(U(.,\phi)) is the same function of U(.,Ï•)U(.,\phi) as P(Uc(.,Ï•))P(U_{c}(.,\phi)) is of Uc(.,Ï•)U_{c}(.,\phi). Then the Bayesian estimator is based on the actual prior. In this case, the Bayesian estimator â„’~Dsubscript~â„’ğ·{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D} will minimize the prior-averaged expected loss of Eq.Â 35.222222To see this, replace â„’~Dsubscript~â„’ğ·{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D} with some arbitrary function of Dğ·D, fâ€‹(D)ğ‘“ğ·f(D). Our task it to solve for the optimal fğ‘“f. First interchange the integrals over data and over oracles in Eq.Â 35. Next consider the integrand of the outer (data) integral, âˆ«dU(.,Ï•)P(U(.,Ï•))âˆi=1Nv(wi)L[f(D),âˆ«dwâ€²U(wâ€²,Ï•)]].\displaystyle\int dU(.,\phi)\;P(U(.,\phi))\prod_{i=1}^{N}v({w}^{i})L[f(D),\;\int d{w}^{\prime}\;U({w}^{\prime},\phi)]]. Since we are considering a noise-free oracle, we can write this as âˆ«dU(.,Ï•)P(U(.,Ï•))P(Dâˆ£v,U(.,Ï•))L[f(D),â„’U(Ï•)].\displaystyle\int dU(.,\phi)\;P(U(.,\phi))P(D\mid v,U(.,\phi))L[f(D),{\mathscr{L}}_{U}(\phi)]. Since P(U(.,Ï•))P(Dâˆ£v,U(.,Ï•))âˆP(U(.,Ï•)âˆ£v,D)=P(U(.,Ï•)âˆ£D)P(U(.,\phi))P(D\mid v,U(.,\phi))\propto P(U(.,\phi)\mid v,D)=P(U(.,\phi)\mid D), this integral is minimized by setting fâ€‹(D)=â„’~Dğ‘“ğ·subscript~â„’ğ·f(D)={\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{D}. QED. In general though, there is no reason to suppose that these two priors are the same. In the real world where those priors differ, expected loss for a Bayesian estimator is given by an inner product between the posterior used by that estimator, P(Uc(.,Ï•)âˆ£D)P(U_{c}(.,\phi)\mid D), and the true posterior, P(U(.,Ï•)âˆ£D)P(U(.,\phi)\mid D)Â (see Wolpert, 1997, 1996).232323It is in recognition of the fact that those functions might differ that we have been referring to â€˜Bayesianâ€™ rather than â€˜Bayes-optimalâ€™ estimators.

As before, since U(.Ï•)U(.\phi) varies in the integrand of prior-averaged expected loss, we can can adapt it to get a prior-averaged expected risk. This is given by

âˆ«dU(.,Ï•)P(U(.,Ï•))âˆ«dw1â€¦dwNâˆi=1Nv(wi)Ã—\displaystyle\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\!\int dU(.,\phi)\;P(U(.,\phi))\int d{w}^{1}\ldots d{w}^{N}\;\prod_{i=1}^{N}v({w}^{i})\;\;\times
{Lâ€‹[â„’~{(wi,Uâ€‹(wi,Ï•))},â„’â€‹(Ï•)]âˆ’minÏâˆˆâ„â€‹[Lâ€‹[Ï,â„’â€‹(Ï•)]]}.ğ¿subscript~â„’superscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–italic-Ï•â„’italic-Ï•subscriptminğœŒâ„delimited-[]ğ¿ğœŒâ„’italic-Ï•\displaystyle\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\{L[{\tilde{\mathscr{L}}}_{\{({w}^{i},U({w}^{i},\phi))\}},\;{\mathscr{L}}(\phi)]\;\;-\;\;{\mbox{min}}_{\rho\in{\mathbb{R}}}[L[\rho,\;{\mathscr{L}}(\phi)]]\}. (36)

As before, if the minimal loss is always 0, then prior-averaged expected risk just equals prior-averaged expected loss.

Broadly speaking, in Bayesian approaches to Monte Carlo problems, the sampling distribution that generated the samples is immaterial once one those samples have been generated Â (see Rasmussen and Gharamani, 2003) and references therein). So what difference does the choice of a sampling distribution like vğ‘£v make to a Bayesian? The answer is that vğ‘£v determines how likely it is that we will generate a Dğ·D with a high posterior variance of the quantity of interest. For example, say one wishes to form an importance sampling estimate of â„’=âˆ«ğ‘‘xâ€‹Uâ€‹(x)â„’differential-dğ‘¥ğ‘ˆğ‘¥{\mathscr{L}}=\int dx\;U(x) using sampling distribution vğ‘£v to generate sample set Dğ·D. Then if one changes vğ‘£v, one changes the likelihoods of the possible Dğ·D. Moreover, each Dğ·D has its own posterior variance, Var(â„’câˆ£D)conditionalsubscriptâ„’ğ‘ğ·({\mathscr{L}}_{c}\mid D). So what a good choice of vğ‘£v means is that a Dğ·D with poor Var(â„’câˆ£D)conditionalsubscriptâ„’ğ‘ğ·({\mathscr{L}}_{c}\mid D) is unlikely to be formed, that is, that âˆ«ğ‘‘Dâ€‹Pâ€‹(Dâˆ£v)â€‹Varâ€‹(â„’câˆ£D)differential-dğ·ğ‘ƒconditionalğ·ğ‘£Varconditionalsubscriptâ„’ğ‘ğ·\int dD\;P(D\mid v){\mbox{Var}}({\mathscr{L}}_{c}\mid D) is low.

6.6 Statistical Analysis of FB MCO

We can extend the statistical analysis of FB MC to the case of FB MCO by allowing Ï•italic-Ï•\phi to vary. The Bayesian choice of Ï•italic-Ï•\phi is the one that minimizes posterior expected loss,

(For example, this is the case with the loss function â„’Uâ€‹(Ï•)subscriptâ„’ğ‘ˆitalic-Ï•{\mathscr{L}}_{U}(\phi) of Eq.Â 4.) Again, since minÏ•â€²â€‹[Lâ€‹(Ï•â€²,U)]subscriptminsuperscriptitalic-Ï•â€²delimited-[]ğ¿superscriptitalic-Ï•â€²ğ‘ˆ{\mbox{min}}_{\phi^{\prime}}[L(\phi^{\prime},U)] typically varies with Uğ‘ˆU, in general this prior-averaged expected risk does not equal the prior-averaged expected loss. However the estimator that minimizes prior-averaged expected loss â€” Ï•~Dsubscript~italic-Ï•ğ·{\tilde{\phi}}_{D} â€” is the same as the estimator that minimizes prior-averaged expected risk.242424This follows from the fact that the prior-averaged lowest possible risk, the term subtracted in Eq.Â 42, is independent of the choice of the estimator.

For any particular fitting algorithm, our equations tell us how performance of the associated FB MCO depends on vğ‘£v and either P(U(.,Ï•))P(U(.,\phi)) or the pair P(U(.,Ï•))P(U(.,\phi)) and P(Uc(.,Ï•))P(U_{c}(.,\phi)), depending on which equation we consider. So if we fix those prior(s), our equations tell us, formally, what the optimal vğ‘£v is.

One can consider estimating that optimal vğ‘£v at a mid-way point of the algorithm, based on the algorithmâ€™s behavior up to that point. One can then set vğ‘£v to that estimate for the remainder of the algorithm.252525Note though that if one intends to update vğ‘£v more than once, then strictly speaking the first update to vğ‘£v should take into account the fact that the future update will occur. That means the equations above for expected loss, prior-averaged expected loss, etc., no longer apply. Doing this essentially amounts to a type of active learning.

As with Bayesian FBMC, we can analyze the effects of having Pâ€‹(U)ğ‘ƒğ‘ˆP(U) not be the same function of Uğ‘ˆU as Pâ€‹(Uc)ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘P(U_{c}) is of Ucsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘U_{c}. Since PL and MCO are formally the same, such an analysis applies to parametric machine learning in addition to FB MCO. In particular, the analysis gives a Bayesian correction to the bias-variance decomposition of supervised learning. This correction holds even if the fitting algorithm in the supervised learning cannot be cast as Bayes-optimal for some assumed prior Pâ€‹(Uc)ğ‘ƒsubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘P(U_{c}). Intuitively speaking, the correction means that the bias-variance decomposition gets replaced by a bias-variance-covariance decomposition. That covariance is between the posterior distribution over target functions on the one hand, and the posterior distribution over fits produced by the fitting algorithm on the otherÂ (see Wolpert, 1997).

6.7 Combining FB and Non-FB Estimates in FB MCO

Return now to the example in Sec.Â 6.6, where the factual sample is formed by importance sampling the factual oracle and we form a fictitious sample set using fictitious oracles.Then using only Dğ·{D}, our estimate of â„±Gâ€‹(Î¸)subscriptâ„±ğºğœƒ{\mathscr{F}}_{G}(\theta) would be the factual estimate, â„±^Dâ€‹(Î¸)=âˆ‘k=1Nrkâ€‹(Î¸)Nsubscript^â„±ğ·ğœƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘superscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘˜ğœƒğ‘{\hat{\mathscr{F}}}_{{D}}(\theta)=\frac{\sum_{k=1}^{N}r^{k}(\theta)}{N}. Using only our fictitious samples would instead give us the estimate â„±~^Dâ€‹(Î¸)subscript^~â„±ğ·ğœƒ{\hat{\tilde{\mathscr{F}}}}_{D}(\theta).

On the one extreme, say we firmly believe that distribution we use for the posterior Pâ€‹(Gcâˆ£D)ğ‘ƒconditionalsubscriptğºğ‘ğ·P({G_{c}}\mid D) is correct. (So in particular we firmly believe that the factual oracle GğºG was generated by sampling the prior Pâ€‹(Gc)ğ‘ƒsubscriptğºğ‘P(G_{c}).) Then in the limit NTâ†’âˆâ†’subscriptğ‘ğ‘‡N_{T}\rightarrow\infty, âˆ€Î¸for-allğœƒ\forall\theta our importance-sample estimate of â„±~Dsubscript~â„±ğ·{\tilde{{\mathscr{F}}}}_{D} will be exactly correct. So Bayesian decision theory would direct us to use the associated estimate â„±~^Dâ€‹(Î¸)subscript^~â„±ğ·ğœƒ{\hat{\tilde{\mathscr{F}}}}_{D}(\theta), and ignore â„±^Dâ€‹(Î¸)subscript^â„±ğ·ğœƒ{\hat{\mathscr{F}}}_{{D}}(\theta). At the other extreme, say that NT=1subscriptğ‘ğ‘‡1N_{T}=1, while Nğ‘N, the number of factual samples, is quite large. In such a situation, even if we believe our posterior is correct, it would clearly be wrong to use â„±~^Dâ€‹(Î¸)subscript^~â„±ğ·ğœƒ{\hat{\tilde{\mathscr{F}}}}_{D}(\theta) as our estimate, ignoring â„±^Dâ€‹(Î¸)subscript^â„±ğ·ğœƒ{\hat{\mathscr{F}}}_{{D}}(\theta).

How should we combine the estimates in this latter situation? More generally, even when we believe our posterior is correct, unless the number of fictitious samples is far greater than the number of factual samples, we should combine the two associated estimates. How best to do that? Does the fact that â„±~^Dâ€‹(Î¸)subscript^~â„±ğ·ğœƒ{\hat{\tilde{\mathscr{F}}}}_{D}(\theta) is estimated via importance sampling over a much larger space than â„±^Dâ€‹(Î¸)subscript^â„±ğ·ğœƒ{\hat{\mathscr{F}}}_{{D}}(\theta) affect how we should combine them? More generally, say we donâ€™t presume that our Pâ€‹(Gcâˆ£D)ğ‘ƒconditionalsubscriptğºğ‘ğ·P({G_{c}}\mid{{D}}) is exactly correct; how should we combine the estimates then?

One is tempted to invoke Bayesian reasoning to determine how best to combine the two estimates. While that might be possible in certain situations, often determining the optimal Bayesian combination would necessitate yet more Monte Carlo sampling of some new integrals. It would be nice if some other approach could be used.

One potential such approach is stackingÂ (Wolpert, 1992; Breiman, 1996; Smyth and Wolpert, 1999). In this approach, one many times partitions the factual sample Dğ·D into two parts, a â€˜training setâ€™ D1superscriptğ·1D^{1}, and a â€˜validation setâ€™ D2superscriptğ·2D^{2}. We write the values of wğ‘¤w and Uğ‘ˆU in D1superscriptğ·1D^{1} as {Dw1â€‹(i)}superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘¤1ğ‘–\{D_{w}^{1}(i)\} and {DU1â€‹(i,Ï•)}superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘ˆ1ğ‘–italic-Ï•\{D_{U}^{1}(i,\phi)\} respectively, and similarly for D2superscriptğ·2D^{2}. For each such partition one would run both the non-FB MCO algorithm and the FB MCO algorithm on D1superscriptğ·1D^{1}. That generates the estimates Ï•^v,U,D1subscript^italic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ·1{\hat{\phi}}_{v,U,D^{1}} and Ï•~^D1subscript^~italic-Ï•superscriptğ·1{\hat{\tilde{\phi}}}_{D^{1}}, respectively.

Those two Ï•italic-Ï•\phiâ€™s give us two associated error values on the validation set, âˆ‘jDU2â€‹(j,Ï•^v,U,D1)subscriptğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘ˆ2ğ‘—subscript^italic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ·1\sum_{j}D_{U}^{2}(j,{\hat{\phi}}_{v,U,D^{1}}) and âˆ‘jDU2â€‹(j,Ï•~^D1)subscriptğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ·ğ‘ˆ2ğ‘—subscript^~italic-Ï•superscriptğ·1\sum_{j}D_{U}^{2}(j,{\hat{\tilde{\phi}}}_{D^{1}}), respectively. More generally, we can evaluate the error on the the validation set of aâ€‹nâ€‹yğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘¦any Ï•italic-Ï•\phi, in addition to the errors of Ï•^v,U,D1subscript^italic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘ˆsuperscriptğ·1{\hat{\phi}}_{v,U,D^{1}} and Ï•~^D1subscript^~italic-Ï•superscriptğ·1{\hat{\tilde{\phi}}}_{D^{1}}. Moreover, we can do this for the validation set of any of the partitions of Dğ·D. Note, however, that only factual samples are used for cross-validation.

This is what stacking exploits. In the most straightforward use of stacking, one searches for a function mapping the Ï•italic-Ï•\phiâ€™s produced by our two algorithms to a composite Ï•italic-Ï•\phi. The goal is to find such a composite Ï•italic-Ï•\phi that will have as small validation set error (when averaged over all partitions) as possible.

For example, if Ï•italic-Ï•\phi is a Euclidean vector, one could perform a regularized search for the weighted sum of Ï•italic-Ï•\phiâ€™s that gives minimal partition-averaged validation set error. Let the weights produced by that search be bFâ€‹Bsubscriptğ‘ğ¹ğµb_{FB} and bnâ€‹oâ€‹nâˆ’Fâ€‹Bsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘œğ‘›ğ¹ğµb_{non-FB}. Then to find the final estimate for Ï•italic-Ï•\phi, one would use those weights to sum the outputs of the algorithms when run on all of Dğ·D: bnâ€‹oâ€‹nâˆ’Fâ€‹Bâ€‹Ï•^v,U,D+bFâ€‹Bâ€‹Ï•~Dsubscriptğ‘ğ‘›ğ‘œğ‘›ğ¹ğµsubscript^italic-Ï•ğ‘£ğ‘ˆğ·subscriptğ‘ğ¹ğµsubscript~italic-Ï•ğ·b_{non-FB}{\hat{\phi}}_{v,U,D}\;+\;b_{FB}{\tilde{\phi}}_{D}.

7 Conclusion

In this paper we explored the relationship between Monte Carlo Optimization of a parametrized integral, parametric machine learning, and â€˜blackboxâ€™ or â€˜oracleâ€™-based optimization. We made four contributions.

First, we proved that MCO is identical to a broad class of parametric machine learning problems. This should open a new application domain for previously investigated parametric machine learning techniques, to the problem of MCO.

To test the use of PL in MCO one needs an MCO problem domain. The one we used was based on our second contribution, which was the introduction of immediate sampling. Immediate sampling is a way to transform an arbitrary blackbox optimization problem into an MCO problem. Accordingly, it provides us a way to test the use of PL to improve MCO, but testing whether it can improve blackbox optimization.

In our third contribution we validated this way of improving blackbox optimization. In particular, we demonstratied that cross-validation and bagging improve immediate sampling.

Conventional Monte Carlo and MCO procedures ignore some features of the sample data. In particular, they ignore the relationship between the sample point locations and the associated values of the integrand; only the values of the integrand at those locations are considered. We ended by presenting fit-based MCO, which is a way to exploit the information in the sample locations.

There are many PL techniques that should be applicable to immediate sampling but that are not experimentally tested in this paper. These include density estimation active learning, stacking, kernel-based methods, boosting, etc. Current and future work involves experimental tests of the ability of such techniques to improve MCO in general and immediate sampling in particular.

Other future work is to conduct experimental investigations of the three techniques that we presented in this paper but did not test. One of these is fit-based MCO (and fit-based immediate sampling in particular). The other two are the techniques described in the appendices: immediate sampling for constrained optimization problems, and immediate sampling with elite objective functions.

There are also many potential application domains for immediate sampling PC for blackbox optimization that we intend to explore. Some of these exploit the ability of such PC to handle arbitrary (mixed) data types of xğ‘¥xâ€™s. In particular, one such data type is the full trajectory of a system through a space; for optimizing a problem over such a space, PC becomes a form of reinforcement learning.

Appendix A Constrained Optimization

Under the PC transform we replace an optimization problem over Xğ‘‹X with one over ğ’¬ğ’¬{\mathscr{Q}}. As discussed at the beginning of Sec.Â 3.3, the characteristics of the transformed objective can be very different from those of the original objective.

Similarly, characteristics of any constraints on Xğ‘‹X in the original problem can also change significantly under this transformation. More precisely, say we add to (P4) equality and inequality constraints restricting xâˆˆXğ‘¥ğ‘‹x\in X to a feasible region. Then to satisfy those Xğ‘‹X-constraints we need to modify (P5) to ensure that the support of the solution qÎ¸(.)q_{\theta}(.) is a subset of the feasible region in Xğ‘‹X.

This appendix considers some ways of modifying PC to do this. For earlier work on this topic in the context of delayed sampling, seeÂ Wolpert etÂ al. (2006); Bieniawski and Wolpert (2004); Bieniawski etÂ al. (2004); Macready and Wolpert (2005).

A.1 Guaranteeing Constraints

Say we have a set of equality and inequality constraints over Xğ‘‹X. Indicate the feasible region by a feasibility indicator function

A.2 Alternative â„±ğ’¢subscriptâ„±ğ’¢{\mathscr{F}}_{{\mathscr{G}}}

Since weâ€™re maximizing our expression over q~Î¸subscript~ğ‘ğœƒ{{\tilde{q}}_{\theta}}, the second, correcting integral in Eq.Â 43 will tend to push q~Î¸subscript~ğ‘ğœƒ{{\tilde{q}}_{\theta}} to have probability mass aâ€‹wâ€‹aâ€‹yğ‘ğ‘¤ğ‘ğ‘¦away from feasible regions. To understand this intuitively, say that q~Î¸subscript~ğ‘ğœƒ{{\tilde{q}}_{\theta}} is a Gaussian and that the feasible region is â€˜spikyâ€™, resembling a multi-dimensional star-fish with a large central region and long, thin legs. For this situation, if we over-concentrate on keeping most of q~Î¸subscript~ğ‘ğœƒ{{\tilde{q}}_{\theta}}â€™s mass restricted to feasible xğ‘¥x, our Gaussian will be pushed away from any of the spikes of the feasible xğ‘¥xâ€™s, and concentrate on the center. If the solution to our original optimization problem is in one of those spikes, such over-concentration is a fatal flaw. The second integral in Eq.Â 43 corrects for this potential problem.

More broadly, consider typical case behavior when one applies some particular constrained optimization algorithm to any of the problems in a particular class of optimization problems. As a practical matter, there is a spectrum of such problem classes, indexed by how difficult it is just to find feasible solutions on typical problems of the class. On the one side of this spectrum are problem classes where it is exceedingly difficult to find such a solution, e.g., high-dimensional satisfiability problems with a performance measure GğºG superimposed to compare potential solutions. On the other end are â€œsimpleâ€ problem classes where it is reasonable to expect to find a feasible solution. The â€˜starfishâ€™ optimization problem is an example of a problem of the former type.282828Note that since we are discussing typical-case behavior, computational complexity considerations do not apply.

For problems on the first side of the spectrum, where just getting a substantial amount of probability mass into the feasible region is very difficult, we may want to leave out the second integral in Eq.Â 43. In other words, we may want to minimize KL(pÎ¦Î²||q~Î¸)(p^{\beta}_{\Phi}\;||\;{\tilde{q}}_{\theta}) rather than KL(pÎ¦Î²||q~Î¦,Î¸)(p^{\beta}_{\Phi}\;||\;{\tilde{q}}_{\Phi,\theta}). The reason to make this change is so that q~Î¸subscript~ğ‘ğœƒ{\tilde{q}}_{\theta} wonâ€™t get pushed away from the feasible region. (As an aside, another potential benefit of this change is that if we make it, then for product distribution q~Î¸subscript~ğ‘ğœƒ{\tilde{q}}_{\theta}, â„±ğ’¢(.){\mathscr{F}}_{{\mathscr{G}}}(.) is convex.)

Even if we do make this change, when we sample the resultant q~Î¸subscript~ğ‘ğœƒ{\tilde{q}}_{\theta} we may not get a feasible xğ‘¥x. If this happens, a natural approach is to repeatedly sample q~Î¸subscript~ğ‘ğœƒ{\tilde{q}}_{\theta} until we do get a feasible xğ‘¥x. However the resultant distribution of xğ‘¥xâ€™s is the same as that formed by sampling q~Î¦,Î¸subscript~ğ‘Î¦ğœƒ{\tilde{q}}_{\Phi,\theta} for the same Î¸ğœƒ\theta. So under this â€™natural approachâ€™ we work to optimize a distribution (q~Î¸subscript~ğ‘ğœƒ{\tilde{q}}_{\theta}) different from the one we ultimately sample (q~Î¦,Î¸subscript~ğ‘Î¦ğœƒ{\tilde{q}}_{\Phi,\theta}). This means that this approach may not properly balance our two conflicting needs for q~Î¸subscript~ğ‘ğœƒ{\tilde{q}}_{\theta}: that it have most of its support in the feasible region, and that it be peaked about xğ‘¥xâ€™s with high pÎ²â€‹(x)superscriptğ‘ğ›½ğ‘¥p^{\beta}(x).

To illustrate this issue differently, take q~Î¸subscript~ğ‘ğœƒ{\tilde{q}}_{\theta} to be normalized, and to avoid multiplying and dividing by zero, modify Î¦â€‹(x)Î¦ğ‘¥\Phi(x) to equal some very small non-zero value Îºğœ…\kappa for infeasible xğ‘¥x (as discussed above). Instead we choose

Appendix B The Elite Objective Function

Not all PC objectives can be cast as an integral transform. Properly speaking, the choice of objective should be set by how the final qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} will be used. For instance, the concept of expected improvement suggested by Â Mockus etÂ al. (1978), and used by Jones etÂ al. (1998), considers an objective (to be maximized) given by maxâ¡(Gbcâˆ’Gâ€‹(x),0)subscriptğºbcğºğ‘¥0\max(G_{\mathrm{bc}}-G(x),0), where GbcsubscriptğºbcG_{\mathrm{bc}} is the best of all the current samples, miniâ¡{Gâ€‹(xi)}subscriptğ‘–ğºsuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–\min_{i}\{G(x^{i})\}. This means that at each step we will take a single sample, and want to maximize the improvement. This is a simplification; even though the next sample may yield any improvement, it may be informative, so that we get a good sample ten steps later. A less simplistic objective is the following:

In blackbox optimization, no matter how many calls to the (factual) oracle we make, we will ultimately choose the best xğ‘¥x (as far as the associated GğºG value is concerned) out of all the ones that were fed to the oracle during the course of the entire run. Our true goal in BO is to have the GğºG associated with tâ€‹hâ€‹aâ€‹tğ‘¡â„ğ‘ğ‘¡that best xğ‘¥x be as small as possible. For a discussion of distributions of extremal values, see Â Leadbetter etÂ al. (1983); Resnick (1987).

Given that qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} varies over the run in a way that we do not know beforehand, how can one approximate this goal as minimizing an objective function that is well-defined at all points during the run? One way to do this is to assume that there is some integer Nğ‘N such that, simultaneously,

  1. 1.

    It is likely that the best xğ‘¥x will be one of the final Nğ‘N calls to the oracle during the run;

  2. 2.

    It is likely that qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} will not vary much during the generation of those final Nğ‘N samples.

Under (2) we can approximate the qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta}â€™s that are used to generate the final Nğ‘N calls as all being equal to some canonical qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta}. Under (1), our goal then becomes finding the canonical qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} that, when sampled Nğ‘N times, produces a set of xğ‘¥xâ€™s whose best element is as good as possible. 313131An obvious variant of this reasoning is to have Nğ‘N vary across the run of the entire algorithm, at any iteration tğ‘¡t being only the number of remaining calls to the oracle that we presume will be made. In this variant, one would modify the elite objective function to only involve the Nâ€‹(t)ğ‘ğ‘¡N(t) remaining samples whose GğºG value is better than the best found by iteration tğ‘¡t. For the case N=1ğ‘1N=1, this is analogous to the expected improvement idea inÂ Jones etÂ al. (1998). Note that this variant objective function will change during the run, which may cause stability problems.

In this appendix we make some cursory comments about this objective function, which we call the elite objective function. We focus on the use of Bayesian FB techniques with this objective. For a noise-free oracle the CDF for the elite objective is

As discussed in Sec.Â 6, it is often good to set Hâ€‹(G)ğ»ğºH(G) to be as close to Pâ€‹(Gâˆ£D)ğ‘ƒconditionalğºğ·P(G\mid D) as possible. To illustrate the foregoing, suppose K=1ğ¾1K=1, and that we have no regularization on qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta}. Then, in general, the sum in Eq.Â 51 is minimized by a qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} that is a delta function about that data point xi1subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘–x^{1}_{i} with the best associated value Giâ€‹(xi1)/hcâ€‹(xi1)subscriptğºğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘¥1ğ‘–G_{i}(x^{1}_{i})/{h_{c}}(x^{1}_{i}). However for K>1ğ¾1K>1, even without regularization, the optimal qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} is not a delta function, in general.333333This suboptimality of a delta function qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} is similar to the suboptimality of having all Kğ¾K pulls in a multi-armed bandit problem be pulls of the same arm. In addition to the regularization-based argument in the text, this gives a more formal reason why the optimal qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} should not be infinitely peaked.

When K>1ğ¾1K>1, the peakedness of qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} parallels the peakedness of another non-negative function over xğ‘¥xâ€™s, namely P(G:G(x)Â is minimized atÂ xâˆ£D)P(G:G(x){\mbox{ is minimized at }}x\mid D). However, if we run a few iterations of FB MCO with the elite objective, then Dğ·D grows, and so P(G:G(x)Â is minimized atÂ xâˆ£D)P(G:G(x){\mbox{ is minimized at }}x\mid D) gets increasingly peaked over xğ‘¥xâ€™s. (Intuitively, the larger Dğ·D is, the more confident we are about GğºG, and consequently the more confident we are about what regions of xğ‘¥xâ€™s minimize GğºG.) Accordingly, qÎ¸subscriptğ‘ğœƒq_{\theta} gets increasingly peaked as the algorithm progresses.

Note that this happens even though there is no external annealing schedule. This reflects the fact that the elite objective has no hyperparameter or regularization parameter like the Î²ğ›½\beta that appears in both the pâ€‹qğ‘ğ‘pq and qâ€‹pğ‘ğ‘qp objective functions.

Appendix C Gaussian Example for Risk Analysis

The following example illustrates the foregoing for the case of Gaussian Ï€ğœ‹\pi, where only moments of Ï€ğœ‹\pi up to order 2 matter.

To illustrate the foregoing, consider the simple case where there are only two Ï•italic-Ï•\phiâ€™s, Ï•1superscriptitalic-Ï•1\phi^{1} and Ï•2superscriptitalic-Ï•2\phi^{2}. Suppose that Uğ‘ˆU and Xğ‘‹X are such that Ï€ğœ‹\pi is a two-dimensional Gaussian. Write Ï€ğœ‹\piâ€™s mean as Î¼ğœ‡\mu. Say that one of Ï€ğœ‹\piâ€™s principal axes is parallel to the diagonal line, l1=l2subscriptğ‘™1subscriptğ‘™2l_{1}=l_{2} (that is, one of the eigenvectors of Ï€ğœ‹\piâ€™s covariance matrix is parallel to the diagonal, and one is orthogonal to the diagonal). Write the standard deviation of Ï€ğœ‹\pi along that diagonal axis as ÏƒAsubscriptğœğ´\sigma_{A}, and write the standard deviation along the other, orthogonal axis as ÏƒBsubscriptğœğµ\sigma_{B}.

Since Ï€ğœ‹\piâ€™s covariance matrix has identical diagonal entries, and since the trace of that matrix is preserved under rotations, those entries are both 12â€‹[ÏƒA2+ÏƒB2]12delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğœğ´2superscriptsubscriptğœğµ2\frac{1}{2}[\sigma_{A}^{2}+\sigma_{B}^{2}]. Since the determinant is preserved, and since ÏƒAsubscriptğœğ´\sigma_{A} is the variance parallel to the diagonal, this in turn means that Ï€ğœ‹\piâ€™s (identical) off-diagonal entries are 12â€‹[ÏƒA2âˆ’ÏƒB2]12delimited-[]superscriptsubscriptğœğ´2superscriptsubscriptğœğµ2\frac{1}{2}[\sigma_{A}^{2}-\sigma_{B}^{2}]. The probability that MCO will choose Ï•1superscriptitalic-Ï•1\phi^{1} is the integral of Ï€ğœ‹\pi over the half-plane where Ï•1â‰¤Ï•2superscriptitalic-Ï•1superscriptitalic-Ï•2\phi^{1}\leq\phi^{2}:

(52)

Varâ€‹[â„’â€‹(Ï•1)]=Varâ€‹[â„’â€‹(Ï•2)]=ÏƒA2+ÏƒB22.Vardelimited-[]â„’superscriptitalic-Ï•1Vardelimited-[]â„’superscriptitalic-Ï•2superscriptsubscriptğœğ´2superscriptsubscriptğœğµ22\displaystyle{\mbox{Var}}[{\mathscr{L}}(\phi^{1})]\;\;=\;\;{\mbox{Var}}[{\mathscr{L}}(\phi^{2})]\;\;=\;\;\frac{\sigma_{A}^{2}+\sigma_{B}^{2}}{2}. So if we shrink the variance of either of the estimators, then we shrink an upper bound on ÏƒBsubscriptğœğµ\sigma_{B}.

For this case of a fixed set of Ï•italic-Ï•\phiâ€™s, it is illuminating to consider the difference between expected loss under a particular MCO algorithm and minimal expected loss over all Ï•italic-Ï•\phiâ€™s, that is, the risk of the MCO algorithm. Assuming Î”â€‹L<0Î”ğ¿0\Delta L<0, it is given by

[Prâ€‹[â„’^â€‹(Ï•2)>â„’^â€‹(Ï•1)]âˆ’Î˜â€‹[â„’â€‹(Ï•2)âˆ’â„’â€‹(Ï•1)]]Ã—[â„’â€‹(Ï•1)âˆ’â„’â€‹(Ï•2)]delimited-[]Prdelimited-[]^â„’superscriptitalic-Ï•2^â„’superscriptitalic-Ï•1Î˜delimited-[]â„’superscriptitalic-Ï•2â„’superscriptitalic-Ï•1delimited-[]â„’superscriptitalic-Ï•1â„’superscriptitalic-Ï•2\displaystyle[{\mbox{Pr}}[{{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}}(\phi^{2})>{{\hat{\mathscr{L}}}}(\phi^{1})]\;-\;\Theta[{\mathscr{L}}(\phi^{2})-{\mathscr{L}}(\phi^{1})]]\;\times\;[{\mathscr{L}}(\phi^{1})\;-\;{\mathscr{L}}(\phi^{2})]
=\displaystyle=
[erfâ¡(Î¼2âˆ’Î¼1ÏƒBâ€‹2)âˆ’Î˜â€‹(Î”â€‹b+Î¼2âˆ’Î¼1)]Ã—[Î¼1âˆ’Î¼2âˆ’Î”â€‹b].delimited-[]erfsubscriptğœ‡2subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœğµ2Î˜Î”ğ‘subscriptğœ‡2subscriptğœ‡1delimited-[]subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡2Î”ğ‘\displaystyle[\operatorname{erf}(\frac{\mu_{2}-\mu_{1}}{\sigma_{B}\sqrt{2}})-\Theta(\Delta b+\mu_{2}-\mu_{1})]\;\times\;[\mu_{1}-\mu_{2}-\Delta b]. Say that Î”â€‹b=0Î”ğ‘0\Delta b=0. Then Eq.Â 55 shows that so long as Î¼1â‰ Î¼2subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡2\mu_{1}\neq\mu_{2}, as ÏƒBâ†’0â†’subscriptğœğµ0\sigma_{B}\rightarrow 0 risk goes to its minimal possible value of zero. So everything else being equal, shrinking the variance of either estimator reduces risk, essentially minimizing it. Alternatively, if we leave the variances of the two estimators unchanged, but increase their covariance, 12â€‹[ÏƒA2âˆ’ÏƒB2]12delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptğœ2ğ´superscriptsubscriptğœğµ2\frac{1}{2}[\sigma^{2}_{A}-\sigma_{B}^{2}], then ÏƒAsubscriptğœğ´\sigma_{A} will increase, while ÏƒBsubscriptğœğµ\sigma_{B} must shrink. So again, the risk will get reduced. For the more general, non-Gaussian case, the high order moments may also come into play.
